episodes.natural_language:
The case, Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022, concerns a dog bite involving a minor, Sariya Mason, born 4/18/2010. The mother, Schrice Thomas, is the designated point of contact. Contact details are as follows: Schrice Thomas, 2328 Quinn Dr., Louisville, KY 40216; cell phone 502-365-0787; email schricethomas@gmail.com. Sariya Mason’s information includes the same address and phone number (2328 Quinn Dr., 40216; 502-365-0787), DOB 4/18/2010, and Ss: 402-73-5118. Insurance coverage lists Passport and Anthem, with Passport ID 0040146051 and Anthem ID FGP922851956. Policy Holders are Sariya Mason and Schrice Thomas, respectively. Billing Information is listed as BI: 2326 Quinn Dr. 40216. The dog involved is a German Shepherd.

Incident details: On August 19, 2022, at approximately 5:15 pm, Sariya was walking down her driveway when the neighbor’s dog—described as a German Shepherd—ran off the porch and bit her, resulting in a laceration to the right thigh that did not require stitches. The incident location is 2328 Quinn Dr., 40216, Jefferson County. EMS responded to the scene but provided no transport; Mother Schrice Thomas subsequently took Sariya to University of Louisville Health – Medical Center Southwest. The incident date is recorded as 8/19/2022 with a listed time of 4:00:00 AM, and the time of the accident is documented as 5:15 PM. EMS services were First-Aid Only. The date of visit to the hospital/urgent care is 8/19/2022, at UofL Health – Medical Center Southwest.

Follow-up and case details: Sariya followed up with her PCP, THR Pediatrics and Wellness, with Dr. Richardson listed as the PCP. The intake was handled by Brandon French, and the associated attorney is Aaron Whaley. At the time of the accident, Sariya was not employed. Related contacts include Schrice Thomas. The county of accident is Jefferson, and the type of animal involved remains a German Shepherd Dog.

The minor has a follow-up appointment this afternoon with their primary care physician. The guardian reports that the bite has not become inflamed or infected to their knowledge. The animal lives at 2326 Quinn Drive, 40216. This same animal had previously attempted to bite the other daughter a few years ago and has also attempted to attack the owner's boyfriend. The owner's name is Castillo; the guardian is unable to pronounce the owner's first name but notes that it contains a Y. The guardian is unsure whether they rent or own the residence. #cc

Recvd Video from Guardian - Neighbor across the street provided to her (Jessica Hackworth) - Reviewed video - Clear shot of Client & neighbors houses - Can see animal running loose, unattended - Client walks down her drive way and animal crosses 2 yards and attacks client unprovoked - Mrs. Hackworth's daughter hears client scream and goes outside and attempts to distract the animal by yelling and whistling - Animal is distracted long enough for Client to enter her home - There are 3 vehicles at the animal's resident, indicating animal should not have been unattended - Can hear Client Guardian yelling at the animal until it returns to its porch - Owners do not seem to respond to commotion outside, animal continues to run loose until end of video #Evidence #Video Footage
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

A video was received from the client's guardian. The neighbor across the street, Jessica Hackworth, provided the video to her, and the video was reviewed. It shows a clear shot of the client and the neighboring houses. The footage depicts an animal running loose and unattended. The client walks down her driveway, and the animal crosses two yards to attack the client unprovoked. Mrs. Hackworth's daughter hears the client's scream, goes outside, and attempts to distract the animal by yelling and whistling. The animal is distracted long enough for the client to enter her home. There are three vehicles at the animal's residence, indicating the animal should not have been unattended. The client's guardian can be heard yelling at the animal until it returns to its porch. The owners do not seem to respond to the commotion outside, and the animal continues to run loose until the end of the video. Evidence: Video Footage.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

__Claim: 04830025 Sariya Mason - Dog Bite__
From: Sarena Tuttle [sarena@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:sarena@whaleylawfirm.com)
To: Nichole.Smith@kyfb.com 
CC: Aaron Whaley [agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com](mailto:agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com)
Date: Fri, 10 Mar 2023 14:22:47 -0500

Good afternoon Nichole,
 Please find attached our office's letter of representation for the
above referenced incident. Your insured's animal (Canine - German Shepherd)
was left unrestrained & unattended on August 19, 2022.
 Our client is a minor neighbor of your insured and was attempting to
walk down her driveway when the animal darts across 2 yards and attacks our
client. We have attached a five (5) minute Ring Doorbell video showing the
events unfold. The animal can be seen moving about the front yard of the
yellow house at the beginning, then at approximate 1:24, our client can be
seen coming down her driveway to the right of the screen. The animal
immediately darts toward & attacks her unprovoked. We have been advised
this is not the 1st incident of this type concerning your insured's animal.
 Please contact our office as soon as possible to discuss an amicable
settlement. We look forward to working with you on this matter. If you have
any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss
them in further detail.

Sarena M. Tuttle
Litigation Paralegal &
Workers' Compensation Case Manager
The Whaley Law Firm
712 Lyndon Lane
Louisville, KY 40222
D: (502) 357-9971
O: (502) 583-4022 ext 104
E: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com
(PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS)
episodes.natural_language:
The case identified as Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022 involves client Sariya Mason, with claim number 04830025 titled “Sariya Mason - Dog Bite.” The matter appears to be documented in an email correspondence dated Friday, March 10, 2023, at 14:22:47 -0500. The email was sent from Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, to Nichole Smith at kyfb.com, with Aaron Whaley cc’d. 

In the body of the message, the sender states that attached is the office’s letter of representation for the above-referenced incident. The email describes your insured’s dog as a German Shepherd that was left unrestrained and unattended on August 19, 2022. The client, a minor and a neighbor of the insured, was attempting to walk down her driveway when the dog darted across two yards and attacked her unprovoked. A five-minute Ring Doorbell video is attached, showing the events: the dog is seen moving about the front yard of the yellow house at the beginning, and at approximately 1:24 the client is seen coming down her driveway to the right of the screen; the dog immediately darts toward and attacks her unprovoked. The sender notes that this is not the first incident of this type concerning the insured’s animal and requests that the matter be discussed to reach an amicable settlement. The email closes with an invitation to contact the office with any questions for further discussion.

Sarena M. Tuttle

episodes.original_body:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Call Back from Guardian - Discussed Low offers (Noted $3500, she believes AW mentioned $10K) - Advised still low for negligence w/scarring - Advised Filed in Jeff Cir Crt - Guardian explained that Def Animal is still running lose around the neighborhood - Elderly Neighbor had to call Animal Control last week as Def Animal attempted to approach her while she was sitting on porch - Advised Guardian that we will Request updated Animal Control Records for Filing with court - Advised will update AW so he can consider asking for order to remove animal - Guardian expressed understanding & appreciated our help. 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: October 02 2023
episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on October 2, 2023, with Sarena regarding the Sariya Mason case. The Guardian called back and we discussed low offers: noted $3,500, she believes AW mentioned $10,000. We advised that the offers are still low for negligence with scarring and that the matter has been filed in Jeff Cir Crt.

The Guardian explained that Def Animal is still running loose around the neighborhood; an elderly neighbor had to call Animal Control last week after Def Animal attempted to approach her while she was sitting on her porch. We advised the Guardian that we will request updated Animal Control Records for filing with the court and will update AW so he can consider asking for an order to remove the animal. The Guardian expressed understanding and appreciation for our help.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. Re: Open Records Request – 2326 Quinn Drive, Louisville, KY 40216.

On November 10, 2023, The Whaley Law Firm sent an open records request to Jefferson County Animal Control (to staff@jeffersoncountyanimalcontrol.com) on behalf of a minor client. The firm represents a minor child who was attacked and injured by a canine residing at 2326 Quinn Drive, Louisville, Kentucky 40216. The letter notes that several reports have been made regarding this animal and its repeated occurrences of being left unrestrained and unsupervised. The request asks for any and all records, reports, inquiries, and any other information your office has regarding this animal, and asks that the office contact them if there are any questions to discuss further. The email was sent from Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971, the office line is (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The note also indicates a new email address.

On Friday, November 17, 2023, at 2:23 PM (Eastern Time), Sarena M. Tuttle sent a follow-up email reiterating that the office had not yet received a response or acknowledgement to the open records request and requesting that the request be processed as soon as possible. The follow-up email was again from Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, using the same contact information and noting the same matter regarding the canine at 2326 Quinn Drive. The message includes the same sign-off with the firm’s address and contact details and again reminds the recipient to contact if there are questions. The signature also states “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.original_body:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

Review of Lou Animal Control Document - July 2019: 1 report of 'Friday' (dog's name) being out unsupervised & acting aggressive (possible client 1st call) - August 2022: Client Incident - Def Cited & Failed to Appear in Court - FTA issued Nov 2022 - Never Picked up - 22-M-005998 CourtNet Print-Out in Investigation Folder - September 2023 - 'Friday' reported as Aggressively approaching another neighbor, Rhonda Turner - Not investigated until a week later - Def given Civil Penalty $150 & Hearing Date w/Board - Def showed for Hearing - Turner did not show - Def claimed Friday is never off his leash or roaming freely - Civil Penalty Dismissed #Investigation
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022 concerns client Sariya Mason. A review of the Lou Animal Control Document from July 2019 notes one report of the dog named 'Friday' being out unsupervised and acting aggressively, which may have been the client’s initial contact.

In August 2022, there was a client incident in which the defendant was cited and failed to appear in court. A failure-to-appear (FTA) was issued in November 2022, and the citation was never picked up. A CourtNet print-out with docket number 22-M-005998 was placed in the investigation folder.

In September 2023, 'Friday' was reported as aggressively approaching another neighbor, Rhonda Turner. The matter was not investigated until a week later. The defendant was issued a civil penalty of $150 and a hearing date with the Board. The defendant appeared for the hearing, while Turner did not appear. The defendant claimed that Friday is never off his leash or roaming freely. The civil penalty was dismissed. #Investigation
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason.

In the matter of Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039), counsel exchanged a series of emails on December 7, 2023. The subject of the thread was the Jefferson Circuit Court case 23-CI-006039, with the parties including Plaintiff Sariya Mason and defendants including Surelis Castillo. The note logs the following sequence of messages and actions.

At 2:56 PM, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) sent an email to Deanna M. Tucker regarding the case. The message stated, “Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039),” and advised that Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and the associated notice had been attached to the filing made that day. He noted that a Word copy was included for convenience and invited any questions. The body of the email included a standard confidentiality disclaimer, indicating the message was intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client privileged or otherwise protected information; it instructed that if the message or attachments were received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not disclose the information.

The email was sent to Deanna M. Tucker, with Sarena Tuttle cc’d. Bryce’s signature block followed, listing The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with the same phone and fax numbers as above.

In a reply later the same day, at 3:13 PM, Deanna M. Tucker—identified in the signature as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, Partner at her firm—acknowledged receipt and requested that her legal assistant be included on future emails. She wrote, “Bryce, Received. If you could include my legal assistant, Kristy King, on emails, that would be appreciated. I have copied her on this email.” Her signature block provided her firm’s address at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, with direct phone number 502.625.1671 and direct fax 502.779.9329. The message contained a confidentiality notice similar to the prior one.

Additionally, the thread shows that Bryce Koon had CC’d Sarena Tuttle on the 2:56 PM message, and in Deanna’s 3:13 PM reply, Kristy M. King was included or copied per Deanna’s instruction. Later, at 3:16 PM, Bryce Koon responded with “Will do,” indicating that he would include Kristy King on future emails.

Throughout these messages, the standard confidentiality and privilege notices were included, reiterating that the communications are intended for the named recipients and should be destroyed or returned if received in error.

Case: Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039). Client: Sariya Mason. The file is labeled Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022.

In December 2023, the matter included a communications thread between The Whaley Law Firm and the opposing counsel. On December 7, 2023, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, emailed Deanna M. Tucker with the subject Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039). He attached Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and the associated notice filed that day, and stated that a Word copy was included for convenience. He identified himself and provided the firm’s contact information: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207. The email also included the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

Deanna Tucker replied later that day: “Bryce, Received. If you could include my legal assistant, Kristy King, on emails, that would be appreciated. I have copied her on this email.” She signed as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, Partner, with the firm’s Louisville address at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; direct phone 502-625-1671; direct fax 502-779-9329. She also included the usual confidentiality notice stating the message is for the named recipient and may be attorney-client or work-product privileged, and that if received in error the recipient should notify the sender and destroy the message.

Following Deanna’s request, Bryce responded: “Will do.” This brief reply was sent on December 7, 2023, to acknowledge that Kristy King would be included on future communications. The exchange—like the prior message—carried The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details and the confidentiality disclaimer.

Then, on January 18, 2024, Bryce Koon sent another email regarding discovery in the same case to Deanna Tucker, with Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King copied. He reported that the responses to the requests for admission had been received, but the responses to the interrogatories and the production of documents remained outstanding. He requested to know when those remaining responses might be expected. The email included his standard signature with the Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville address and contact numbers (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363) and again carried the confidentiality notice.

In summary, the December 7, 2023 filing established Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and its notice, followed by acknowledgment and a request to include Kristy King in future communications; and on January 18, 2024, the team followed up to note that admissions responses had been received while interrogatories and document production remained outstanding and to request a timeline for those remaining responses.

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. This note documents discovery communications in the matter Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court case number 23-CI-006039.

The communications originate from W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky, and were sent to Deanna M. Tucker (with several colleagues copied) over a period spanning December 2023 to January 2024. The file shows a consistent pattern of follow-up on outstanding discovery responses in the Jefferson County case.

On December 7, 2023, Bryce Koon emailed Deanna Tucker to transmit Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and the associated notice filed that day. He advised that a Word copy of the discovery material was included for convenience and asked counsel to review and let him know if there were any questions. The Whaley Law Firm signature in this message lists 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 237-3207. Additionally, the email included a standard confidentiality notice indicating the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged information, with instructions should the message have been received in error.

Deanna Tucker replied on December 7, 2023, at 3:13 PM, acknowledging receipt and requesting that her legal assistant, Kristy King, be included on emails going forward; she noted that she had copied Kristy on the email. Tucker’s signature in this chain identifies her as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, Partner, with an office at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202. Her direct phone is 502.625.1671 and her direct fax is 502.779.9329. A confidentiality notice was included in the exchange, stating the communication is privileged and should be treated accordingly if received in error.

Earlier that same day, at 2:56 PM, Bryce had written to Deanna Tucker with a brief: “Good afternoon counsel,” and advised that Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery had been attached, along with a Word copy for convenience. He also noted that he would “will do” regarding including Ms. King on future emails, in response to Tucker’s request.

The next message in the thread, at 3:15 PM on December 7, 2023, shows Deanna Tucker replying with the acknowledgment “Will do,” confirming her amendment to include Kristy King on communications.

Moving forward to January 18, 2024, Bryce Koon sent another follow-up to Deanna Tucker. He stated that he wished to follow up on the discovery requests served in the matter and noted that, so far, the responses appeared to include answers to the requests for admission, but the responses to interrogatories and the production of documents remained outstanding. He asked Deanna to advise when such responses could be expected. This January 18 message also includes the standard firm signature for The Whaley Law Firm, repeating the Louisville address, phone, and fax numbers, along with the confidentiality notice.

Finally, on January 31, 2024, Bryce Koon sent another concise follow-up to Deanna Tucker. He wrote to again request information on the outstanding discovery responses and asked that she advise when they may be expected. This email again carried the standard Whaley Law Firm signature block and confidentiality notice.

Across the thread, the communications consistently reference the case caption Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court case 23-CI-006039. The correspondence also reflects standard attorney‑client privilege notices and the practice of including Kristy M. King, Deanna Tucker’s requested legal assistant, on email communications. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details appear in the signatures, with minor variations in fax numbers between messages.

The message also contained a confidentiality notice, indicating the communication and any attachments were intended only for the recipient(s) named and may be subject to attorney-client and/or work product privileges.

Later the same afternoon, at 3:15 PM, Bryce Koon replied, indicating “Will do.” The exchange at that time carried the same general subject matter and the same discovery documents and intent.

On January 18, 2024, at 3:18 PM, Bryce Koon again followed up with Deanna Tucker regarding the discovery requests. He noted that, while answers to the requests for admission appeared to have been received, responses to the interrogatories and to the production of documents remained outstanding, and he asked when those responses could be expected. The message again carried the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

A few days later, on January 31, 2024, at 1:08 PM, Koon sent another follow-up. He stated he was writing to again pursue the outstanding discovery responses and asked Deanna Tucker to advise when those responses may be expected. The note included the attorney’s contact information and the same confidential-disclaimer language.

Then, on February 14, 2024, at 4:09 PM, Koon sent a final follow-up to counsel. He acknowledged that the parties had been attempting for some time to obtain responses to the interrogatories and the requests for production of documents previously served. He stated that, while he did not wish to engage in extraneous litigation, if there was no response by this time next week, they would be forced to file a motion to compel in this regard. The message again included The Whaley Law Firm’s professional contact information and the standard confidentiality notice.

Throughout the correspondence, the communications repeatedly reference the same active matter: Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-006039. The note reflects ongoing efforts to obtain full discovery responses (interrogatories and production of documents), with occasional partial responses (notably admissions) and repeated follow-ups over a period extending from December 2023 through February 2024. The law firm contact details for The Whaley Law Firm (Bryce Koon, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) appear in the December 7, 2023 and February 14, 2024 messages. Deanna M. Tucker’s responses consistently indicate the need to include her legal assistant (Kristy M. King) on communications, a request Tucker conveyed in her December 7, 2023 reply.

In sum, the record shows a back-and-forth sequence of discovery-related emails beginning with the December 7, 2023 transmission of Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery, followed by multiple follow-ups in January 2024 and a further reminder in February 2024, with counsel warning of a possible motion to compel if the outstanding interrogatories and document productions are not addressed within a stated timeframe.

Case: Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039). Client: Sariya Mason. This narrative summarizes the email correspondence between counsel handling the matter and traces discovery and motion scheduling activity in the case.

On February 21, 2024, at 16:33:49 (UTC-05:00), W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Deanna M. Tucker, Esq., with copies to Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King. He stated, “Good afternoon counsel, Please see attached filed today and set for next Monday’s motion hour.” The message included Koon’s contact information for The Whaley Law Firm—712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, phone 502-365-5043, fax 502-364-9363—and a standard attorney-client privilege confidentiality notice indicating the message is intended only for the named recipient and warning against sharing or using the information if received in error. The same day, the thread shows the ongoing pattern of discovery-related communications between the parties, with the expectation that the attached filing would be addressed during the upcoming motion hour the following Monday.

Earlier in the chain, on February 14, 2024, at 16:09 (UTC-05:00), Koon wrote to Deanna M. Tucker, stating, “As you can see below, we have been attempting for some time now to obtain responses to the interrogatories and requests for production of documents we previously served. While I do not wish for any extraneous litigation, if we do not hear back from you by this time next week we will be forced to file a motion to compel in this regard.” He concluded with his standard firm signature and confidentiality notice.

The record also includes an earlier follow-up from January 31, 2024, at 13:08 (UTC-05:00), in which Koon wrote, “Good afternoon Deanna, I am writing to again follow up on the outstanding discovery responses. Please advise when these may be expected.” The January 31 message was accompanied by Koon’s firm contact details and the usual confidentiality language.

Prior to that, on January 18, 2024, at 15:18 (UTC-05:00), Koon sent a message: “Good afternoon Deanna, Just wanted to follow up on the discovery requests served in this regard. It appears we have received answers to the requests for admission but the responses to interrogatories and production of documents remain outstanding. Please advise when we may expect such responses.” The message again carried Koon’s signature and confidentiality notice.

The chain includes December 7, 2023, at 3:15 PM, in which Koon replied simply, “Will do.” The preceding December 7, 2023, at 3:13 PM, shows Deanna M. Tucker replying to Bryce Koon, requesting that her legal assistant, Kristy King, be included on emails and noting that she had copied Kristy on the email.

Earlier still, on December 7, 2023, at 2:56 PM, Koon wrote, “Attached please find Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and the associated notice filed today. A word copy is included for your convenience. If you have any questions, please let me know.” The email carried The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and the standard confidentiality boilerplate.

In December 2023, Deanna M. Tucker’s reply — dated December 7, 2023 at 3:13 PM — confirmed receipt and requested that her legal assistant, Kristy King, be included on emails, noting she had copied Kristy on the current exchange and reiterating confidentiality of the communications.

Across these exchanges, the central issues have been discovery-related: the plaintiffs’ counsel (W. Bryce Koon, Esq.) has been seeking responses to interrogatories and requests for production of documents, with explicit reminders that failure to respond could lead to a motion to compel; the record also shows that the plaintiff filed a First Set of Discovery, including a notice, in December 2023, and that communications continued into February 2024 regarding the status of discovery responses and scheduling of motions.

This case concerns Sariya Mason as the plaintiff against Surelis Castillo and others, in Jefferson County Circuit Court, docket 23-CI-006039. The parties’ correspondence reflects ongoing discovery efforts and the procedural step of setting a motion hour for a forthcoming filing, with multiple follow-ups aimed at obtaining timely responses to discovery requests and avoiding unnecessary litigation through proactive resolution of discovery disputes.

In the matter of Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court case 23-CI-006039, a follow-up email was sent on January 18, 2024. W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to Deanna M. Tucker, with Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King copied on the thread, to address the status of discovery requests in the case. He noted that answers to the requests for admission had been received, but the responses to the interrogatories and the production of documents remained outstanding, and he asked Deanna to advise when such responses could be expected. The email included counsel contact details for The Whaley Law Firm—712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax number of (502) 364-9363—and carried the standard attorney-client confidentiality disclaimers typical of the firm.

This January 18, 2024 email followed a prior exchange dated December 7, 2023. In the earlier communications, Bryce Koon sent out Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery along with the associated notice filed that day, noting that a Word copy of the set was included for convenience. The email was addressed to Deanna M. Tucker and copied to Sarena Tuttle, with the subject line identifying the same case (Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039). The message stated that a Word copy was included and invited any questions.

Deanna M. Tucker responded later on December 7, 2023, at 3:13 PM, asking that her legal assistant, Kristy King, be included on future emails and noting that she had copied Kristy on the email. Tucker signed as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, a Partner, and provided her contact information: 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502.625.1671; Direct Fax: 502.779.9329. Her message also contained the firm’s confidentiality notice, indicating the communication and attachments were intended for the named recipient(s) and protected by attorney-client and work product privileges, with instructions on what to do if received in error.

 Bryce Koon replied to Tucker at 3:15 PM on December 7, 2023 with a simple confirmation, “Will do,” indicating he would include Kristy King on future communications as Tucker requested. This exchange, like the prior one, was accompanied by the standard confidentiality disclaimer stating that the message may contain attorney-client privileged or protected information and advising the recipient to contact The Whaley Law Firm if the message was received in error and not to disclose or forward it.

In summary, the case note documents a January 18, 2024 follow-up confirming that admissions responses had been received but that interrogatories and document production responses were still outstanding; it also recounts the December 7, 2023 sequence in which Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery was sent, Tucker’s request to include Kristy King on emails, and Bryce Koon’s acknowledgment of that request. The correspondence includes the parties’ contact details and the confidentiality and privilege notices that accompanied each email.

Case: Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. in Jefferson Circuit Court, 23-CI-006039. The client is Sariya Mason, and the file is labeled Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. The record consists of a chain of email communications between W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, and Deanna M. Tucker, a partner at SBMK Law, with Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King copied on various messages.

On December 7, 2023, at 2:56 p.m., Bryce Koon sent Deanna Tucker a message attaching Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and the notice filed that day, noting that a Word copy was included for her convenience. The email also contained The Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality notice. The CC line included Sarena Tuttle, and Kristy M. King was cc’d in subsequent correspondence.

Deanna Tucker replied at 3:13 p.m. on the same day, requesting that her legal assistant, Kristy King, be included on emails and noting that she had copied Kristy on the email. She signed as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, Partner, with the Louisville, Kentucky address and direct contact details, and the message also carried the confidentiality notice.

Bryce Koon responded shortly thereafter at 3:15 p.m. with a brief "Will do," and his signature block again listed The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information.

In the following month, on January 18, 2024, at 3:18 p.m., Koon again wrote to Deanna Tucker regarding discovery in the Mason case. He advised that the discovery requests had been served and noted that responses had been received for the requests for admission, but that responses to interrogatories and the production of documents remained outstanding. He asked Deanna to advise when those remaining responses could be expected, and he concluded with his standard contact information and confidentiality notice, with Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King cc’d on the email.

Finally, on January 31, 2024, at 1:08 p.m., Koon sent another follow-up to Deanna Tucker regarding the outstanding discovery responses. He again requested guidance on when the responses may be expected and closed with his contact information and the confidentiality notice. The CC on this message included Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King, and the email carried the subject line RE: Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039).

Throughout these exchanges, the emails repeatedly contained attorney-client privilege and confidentiality notices, and the sender’s firm information appeared in the signatures: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with phone numbers 502-365-5043 and fax numbers 502-364-9363 (and 502-237-3207 in earlier messages). The recipient list included Deanna M. Tucker of SBMK Law, with Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King consistently copied. The subject lines in each message consistently referenced the case Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039.

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

This note summarizes a sequence of email communications in the matter of Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., Jefferson Circuit Court case number 23-CI-006039. The communications involve counsel for the plaintiff, W. Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm, and counsel for the defendants, Deanna M. Tucker. The note traces discovery-related correspondence beginning in December 2023 and continuing through February 2024, culminating in a filing that was attached to an email on February 21, 2024 and set for the following Monday’s motion hour.

On December 7, 2023, Bryce Koon sent an email to Deanna Tucker attaching Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and the associated notice filed that day, and he noted that a Word copy was included for convenience. The message contains the standard confidentiality and privilege notices typical of electronic correspondence from counsel, and the Whaley Law Firm’s contact details were included: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of 502-365-5043 and a fax number listed as 502-237-3207 in this instance. In the same thread, Deanna Tucker replied later that day (3:13 PM) requesting that her legal assistant, Kristy King, be included on emails, and she provided her own signature with the firm’s confidential notice. Bryce Koon responded shortly thereafter (3:15 PM) confirming that Kristy King would be included on future emails.

Earlier, on January 18, 2024 (3:18 PM), Koon followed up on the discovery requests, noting that responses to the requests for admission had been received, but that the interrogatories and production of documents remained outstanding, and he asked when such responses could be expected. He included his standard firm signature and contact information, with the fax number listed as 502-364-9363 in this message. The confidentiality and privilege notices were again part of the email footer.

On January 31, 2024, Koon again wrote Deanna Tucker to follow up on the outstanding discovery responses, requesting an update on when they may be expected. The message continued to bear the Whaley Law Firm’s identifying information and the customary confidentiality disclaimer.

On February 14, 2024, Koon sent another reminder, noting that, “as you can see below,” the law firm had been attempting to obtain responses for some time. He stated that if they did not hear back by the following week, they would be forced to file a motion to compel regarding discovery responses. This message again carried his standard signature and the confidentiality notice.

Finally, on February 21, 2024, Koon sent a good-afternoon counsel email informing Deanna Tucker that the attached filing had been filed that day and was set for the next Monday’s motion hour. The message indicates that the filing was associated with the Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo matter, and it reiterates the ongoing scheduling of a motion hour. The February 21 email also lists the same recipients as in prior messages, with Deanna Tucker as the primary recipient and Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King CC’d. The signature again identifies The Whaley Law Firm and provides the Louisville address, the phone line, and the fax line (this time listing the fax as 502-364-9363). As with the prior messages, the email includes the standard confidentiality and privilege notices.

Across the chain, the key facts include: the case caption and docket number of Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, Jefferson Circuit, 23-CI-006039; the plaintiff’s first set of discovery and accompanying notice filed December 7, 2023; ongoing discovery responses (specifically, admitted responses obtained, but interrogatories and production of documents still outstanding); repeated follow-ups from counsel requesting prompt production of these documents and responses; and the intent to seek relief by way of a motion to compel if responses were not forthcoming by the stated deadlines. The communications also show a routine practice of including Kristy M. King, Deanna Tucker’s assistant, on correspondence and the use of standard client-attorney privilege and confidentiality notices in each email.

The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details appear in the signature blocks across the messages, with the Louisville, Kentucky address of 712 Lyndon Lane, 40222, a landline of 502-365-5043, and the fax number varying between 502-237-3207 in December 2023 messages and 502-364-9363 in later messages (including the February 21, 2024 email). Deanna Tucker’s communications from this period also included a confidentiality notice and her role as a partner at the firm located at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, KY 40202, with direct phone 502-625-1671 and direct fax 502-779-9329.

In summary, this case has a documented history of discovery activity beginning with the December 2023 filing of the plaintiff’s first set of discovery, followed by a series of communications pressing for timely responses to interrogatories and production requests, and culminating in a February 21, 2024 email announcing a filed filing and a scheduled motion hour for the following Monday. The exchange reflects ongoing efforts to resolve discovery disputes with the potential for a motion to compel if timely responses were not provided.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Guardian VM - Returned her call - Advised DC has provided Answer to Complaint & RFA - DC has not responded to Interrogatories/RFPD - Advised Client DC requested Extension until March 11, 2024 - Discuss after DC Resp to Disc Req is received we will move to Oral Discovery & will request to Depose Def Animal Owner & Def Home Owner if needed - Advised these are items she will not be actively involved in but she is welcome to call for a status update at any time - She expressed understanding & appreciated the update

episodes.natural_language:
This case, Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022, involves client Sariya Mason. On March 5, 2024, Sarena made contact after returning a voicemail left by the client’s guardian. 

During the contact, the guardian was advised that the defendant had provided an Answer to the Complaint and to the Request for Admissions (RFA). The defendant has not responded to the Interrogatories or to the Requests for Production of Documents (RFPD). The guardian was advised that the defendant requested an extension until March 11, 2024. 

We discussed that after the defendant’s responses to the discovery requests are received, we will move to oral discovery and may request to depose the defendant animal owner and the defendant home owner if needed. It was explained that these are items the guardian will not be actively involved in, but she is welcome to call for a status update at any time. The guardian expressed understanding and appreciated the update. This contact was made by Sarena on March 5, 2024.

episodes.natural_language:
This case file, labeled Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022, concerns client Sariya Mason in the matter of Shrice Thomas (Saryia Mason) v. Castillo in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-006039. The Re line in the correspondence reflects the same case: Shrice Thomas (Saryia Mason) v. Castillo (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039).

The email communications involve Matthew Londergan of SBM-KY Law and W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, with Sarena Tuttle CC’d on the thread. On February 23, 2024, Bryce Koon sent Matt Londergan an email with the subject Shrice Thomas (Saryia Mason) v. Castillo (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039). He asked Matt to review the attached notice of remand and stated that he would follow up in a couple of weeks. Bryce provided his contact information and included a standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer. There was an attachment indicated as a PNG file named 7B2639118C3B465BB62F885EB3C529AB[7722345].png. The message also carried a confidentiality notice: it was intended only for the named recipient, and if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, with no waiver of privilege, and should not forward the information to anyone not intended to receive it.

On March 18, 2024, Bryce wrote again to Matt with the subject Shrice Thomas (Saryia Mason) v. Castillo (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039). In that message, dated Friday, February 23, 2024 at 10:10 AM (the prior message’s date appears here, but it is part of the same thread), Bryce said: “Matt, Please see the attached notice of remand. I will follow back up with you in a couple of weeks. Thank you for your assistance in this regard.” This email, like the previous one, included Bryce’s firm contact information, a PNG attachment, and the confidentiality disclaimer. The recipient listed was mlondergan@sbmkylaw.com, with Sarena Tuttle CC’d, and the subject remained the same. The PNG attachment is again indicated as 7B2639118C3B465BB62F885EB3C529AB[7722345].png.

Further down the same March 18, 2024 thread, around 2:18 PM (the record notes a question mark next to the exact time), Bryce wrote: “Good afternoon Matt, Just wanted to follow up and see if you have gotten the discovery responses. Thanks.” The signature again included Bryce Koon’s credentials and contact information, along with the standard confidentiality language and the same PNG attachment placeholder.

Later that day, at 22:13:53 +0000, Matthew Londergan replied to Bryce. In his message, he explained that he was out of the office on vacation until Wednesday and that they were working on finalizing the discovery responses, adding that he anticipated having them ready no later than the following week. This reply was sent to Bryce Koon, with Sarena Tuttle CC’d, and, like the earlier messages, contained the confidentiality disclaimer and the PNG attachment indicator.

In summary, the chain of correspondence in this case centers on the February 23, 2024 notice of remand, a March 18, 2024 follow-up from Bryce regarding discovery responses, and a March 18, 2024 response from Matt indicating a temporary absence and an expectation to complete the discovery responses by the following week, all within the context of attachments and standard privilege/confidentiality notices.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Text to Client with Update:

Good afternoon Schrice,
We just wanted to update you that we are still awaiting the Defense Response to Discovery Requests that were sent to them to collect additional information. The Defense Attorney has advised that we should have these responses by the end of next week. Once the Responses are received and reviewed, Bryce or I will reach out to you to discuss the next steps in Sariya's claim. episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

Case context:
In the matter of Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., filed in Jefferson Circuit Court (docket number 23-CI-006039), a sequence of discovery communications occurred between counsel at The Whaley Law Firm and counsel at SBM Legal Group. The primary contacts were W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, representing the plaintiff, Sariya Mason, and Deanna M. Tucker, Esq., a partner at SBM, representing the defendant group. Kristy M. King, a legal assistant at SBM, and Sarena Tuttle, and others at the two firms were copied on various communications. The emails repeatedly noted that they contained attorney-client privileged material and were not to be disclosed if received in error.

December 7, 2023 communications:
- At 2:56 PM, Bryce Koon sent an email to Deanna M. Tucker with the subject Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039). He attached Plaintiff’s First Set of Discovery and the associated notice filed that day and stated that a Word copy was included for convenience. He asked Deanna to contact him with any questions.
- At 3:13 PM, Deanna Tucker replied, noting that Bryce should include her legal assistant, Kristy King, on email communications and that she had copied Kristy on the present email.
- At 3:15 PM, Bryce Koon responded confirming the same, and he continued the thread with the parties and copies as appropriate.

January 2024 follow-up communications:
- January 18, 2024, at 3:18 PM, Bryce Koon sent a follow-up message to Deanna Tucker. He stated that discovery responses had been outstanding, including interrogatories and production of documents, and he requested that Deanna advise when they could be expected. He reiterated that there should be no waiver of privilege and that the messages were intended for the named recipient.
- January 31, 2024, at 1:08 PM, Bryce Koon again followed up with Deanna Tucker, asking for an update on the outstanding discovery responses and when they might be expected.
- January 18 and January 31 messages repeatedly referenced the parties’ ongoing efforts to obtain the plaintiff’s responses (interrogatories and production of documents) and warned that, absent timely responses, a motion to compel could be pursued.

February 2024 prior to the March 2024 disclosure:
- February 7 or early February communications are noted in the record through February 14, 2024, at 4:09 PM. In this message, Bryce Koon stated that they had been attempting to obtain responses for some time and, while not seeking extraneous litigation, if no response was received by the following week, a motion to compel would be filed. He reiterated that the case involved interrogatories and requests for production of documents.
- February 21, 2024, at 4:34 PM, Bryce Koon reported that “today” they had filed something related to the discovery and that the matter was set for next Monday’s motion hour. He signed as counsel for The Whaley Law Firm and included standard attorney-client disclaimers.

March 25, 2024 communication:
- On March 25, 2024, Kristy M. King, Legal Assistant for SBM, sent an email concerning the same case. In this message, she stated that attached were the Defendant’s discovery responses and document production. She noted that a hard copy would not follow by mail unless requested. The email included her contact information (address, direct phone, and direct fax) and bore SBM’s confidentiality notice. The communication was directed to counsel at The Whaley Law Firm (Bryce Koon and Deanna M. Tucker) and copied Sarena Tuttle and Matthew Londergan.

Additional notes:
- The chain repeatedly employed the standard confidentiality language typical of attorney communications, indicating that the messages and attachments were intended for the named recipients and may be privileged; if received in error, recipients were instructed to notify the sender and destroy the materials.
- Throughout the timeline, the subject line for these communications consistently referenced Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039), and messages circulated among Bryce Koon, Deanna Tucker, Kristy King, Sarena Tuttle, and others at both law firms.
- The March 25, 2024 message confirms the defendant’s discovery responses and document production had been assembled and sent electronically, with a note that a hard copy would not be mailed unless requested.

In summary, from December 2023 through March 2024, the parties engaged in a back-and-forth sequence regarding discovery responses and document production in the Jefferson Circuit case 23-CI-006039, with multiple follow-ups by The Whaley Law Firm indicating delays and potential motions to compel, culminating in a March 25, 2024 email transmitting the defendant’s discovery responses and production and noting no required hard-copy mailing unless requested.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. The record documents a sequence of discovery-related communications in the case Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., filed in Jefferson Circuit Court (Jefferson Circuit 23-CI-006039) and carried through spring 2024. The sender in most communications is W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, Kentucky (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-364-9363, though an earlier message shows a different fax number). The recipient list includes Deanna M. Tucker of SBMKY Law (dtucker@sbmkylaw.com) and her co-counsel, Deanna M. Tucker, along with other recipients such as Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King. The communications repeatedly reference the discovery responses and document productions associated with the defendant in this matter, as well as the scheduling of motions for their motion hour. Each email contains a confidentiality notice typical of attorney communications.

On December 7, 2023, Deanna M. Tucker replied to Bryce Koon, noting that Bryce should include her legal assistant, Kristy King, on future emails and indicating she had copied Kristy on the exchange. She signed as Deanna M. Tucker, a partner at her firm, with the email signature including her Louisville address and direct contact details. A confidentiality notice accompanied this and related messages.

On January 18, 2024, Bryce followed up again, stating that, although answers to the requests for admission had been received, responses to the interrogatories and the production of documents remained outstanding. He indicated that, while he did not want extraneous litigation, a motion to compel would be pursued if no responses were forthcoming.

The next day, January 31, 2024, Bryce again reached out to Deanna Tucker, asking to be advised when the outstanding discovery responses could be expected. The correspondence continued the theme of pressing for complete discovery.

On February 14, 2024, Bryce sent another message to Deanna Tucker, reiterating that attempts had been ongoing for some time to obtain responses to the interrogatories and requests for production. He warned that if they did not hear back by the following week, they would be compelled to file a motion to compel. This message again carried the standard confidentiality boilerplate.

A subsequent email on February 21, 2024, from Bryce Koon stated that the attached filing had been made that day and was set for the next Monday’s motion hour. The chain notes that this is in the Jefferson Circuit case identified as 23-CI-006039, and the message reiterates the motion-hour scheduling.

On March 25, 2024, Kristy M. King, serving as legal assistant, sent a message to Bryce Koon and Deanna Tucker (with Sarena Tuttle and Matthew Londergan CC’d) reporting that the defendant’s discovery responses and document production were attached. She indicated that a hard copy would not follow by mail unless requested and invited any questions. The message carries a confidentiality notice typical of such communications.

Finally, on April 11, 2024, Bryce Koon sent Good morning emails to counsel stating that the attached motion had been filed that day and was set for Monday’s motion hour. He included a full signature block for The Whaley Law Firm, with the Louisville address and contact information. The record shows the ongoing coordination around the motion and the discovery matters in Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al., in Jefferson Circuit Court (23-CI-006039). The April 11 message also includes the standard attorney-confidentiality notices typical of such communications.

In summary, over late 2023 and early to mid-2024, the parties repeatedly corresponded about outstanding discovery responses (interrogatories and document production), with admissions responses already provided, and ongoing efforts culminating in the filing of a motion (and scheduling for the motion hour) in the Jefferson Circuit case 23-CI-006039, all linked to the representation of Sariya Mason by The Whaley Law Firm and the opposing counsel, Deanna M. Tucker of SBMKY Law, along with several supporting staff.

On December 7, 2023, Deanna M. Tucker replied to a message from W. Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm regarding the Sariya Mason matter. Bryce’s signature on that message shows The Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville, Kentucky office at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with a phone number of (502) 365-5043 and a fax of (502) 237-3207.

He stated that, although they had received answers to the requests for admission, the responses to the interrogatories and the production of documents remained outstanding. He emphasized that, while he did not seek unnecessary litigation, if no responses were received by the following week, he would be forced to file a motion to compel the discovery responses.

In a February 14, 2024 message, Bryce again referenced the ongoing efforts to obtain responses to the interrogatories and production requests, reiterating that they had been attempting to obtain these for some time. He warned that, if they did not hear back within a week, they would be compelled to file a motion to compel. The message again reiterated the intention to move forward if there was no timely response.

On February 21, 2024, Bryce informed counsel that the attached document had been filed and that the matter was set for next Monday’s motion hour, signaling a scheduled hearing related to the discovery issues. His message reiterated the standard Whaley Law Firm closing and included the firm’s signature block with the same Louisville address and contact information.

Meanwhile, on March 25, 2024, Kristy M. King, identified as a Legal Assistant for The Whaley Law Firm, sent a message to Bryce Koon and Deanna M. Tucker, with Sarena Tuttle and Matthew Londergan CC’d. King stated that the attached documents contained Defendant’s discovery responses and document production, and noted that a hard copy would not be mailed unless requested. King’s message also included her direct contact details: 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502-625-1706; Direct Fax: 502-583-4780. The email also contained a confidentiality notice typical of attorney communications, underscoring that the content is for the named recipients and may be privileged.

Finally, on April 11, 2024, Bryce Koon sent another communication to counsel, again noting that the attached motion had been filed that day and that it was set for Monday’s motion hour. This message continued the pattern of motion practice related to the discovery issues in the Mason case, with the same general recipients and cc’d parties. Bryce’s message was sent from The Whaley Law Firm at the same Louisville address and contact numbers.

In sum, between December 2023 and April 2024, counsel for Sariya Mason and the defense in Sariya Mason v. Surelis Castillo, et al. engaged in a back-and-forth regarding discovery responses, with multiple follow-ups from Bryce Koon, a March 2024 transmission of the defendant’s discovery responses and production, and two motions being set for hearing in connection with the discovery disputes (one set for the next Monday following February 21, 2024, and another set for the Monday following April 11, 2024). The communications were distributed among Bryce Koon, Deanna M. Tucker, Kristy M. King, Sarena Tuttle, and Matthew Londergan, with Kristy King formally included as the recipient as of March 25, 2024 and the chain preserving the confidentiality notices customary to such attorney communications.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd Guardian VM - Returned her call - Getting Frustrated with the process - Explained that we did receive Def Resp to Disc Req and they are placing fault on 'mom' who was watching the animal - Trying to get 'mom' served - Sheriff's are attempting - No Deadline to get served - Asked about Resp to DC Disc Req - She states she has not received the request or discussed them with anyone - Requested email to send them to - ShriceThomas@Gmail.com - Attempted to send DC Disc Req PP Client via email - Email was kicked back - Ran Lexis Search - Email is @Yahoo.com - Resent - That one Kicked back as well - Sending Client Text - Client admits she does not use email - Possible emails have been closed due to inactivity 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: May 15 2024
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason.

On May 15, 2024, Sarena made initial contact regarding the case with client Sariya Mason. The record notes that a guardian voicemail was received, and we returned her call. The client is getting frustrated with the process. We explained that we did receive the Defendant’s Response to the Discovery Request, and that the opposing party is placing fault on the “mom” who was watching the animal. We are trying to get “mom” served, and the sheriff’s office is attempting service; there is no deadline to get served.

We asked the client about the Defendant’s Response to the Discovery Request (DC Disc Req). She stated that she has not received the request or discussed it with anyone. She requested an email address to send them to: ShriceThomas@Gmail.com. We attempted to send the DC Discovery Request to the client via email, but the email was kicked back. We ran a Lexis search; the email on file is @Yahoo.com. We resent to that address, but it was kicked back as well. We then sent a text to the client; she admitted she does not use email, and noted that possible emails may be closed due to inactivity.
episodes.author: Filevine Integration

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. The matter is listed as “Re: Castillo adv. Thomas.”

On June 25, 2024, in the email thread related to the Castillo matter, Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, a Partner, sent a message asking Aaron Whaley for a one-week extension on the Answer date for Ms. Vilches. The message was written to Aaron Whaley and was addressed to Bryce Koon, Deanna M. Tucker, and Sarena Tuttle, with the subject line Re: Castillo adv. Thomas. In the body of the email, Deanna wrote: “Aaron, May I have a one-week extension on the Answer date for Ms. Vilches? Thank you in advance for your anticipated courtesy.” Her signature followed, listing her title as Partner and her office address at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, along with Direct Phone: 502.625.1671 and Direct Fax: 502.779.9329. The email included a logo image and a confidentiality notice stating that the communication is intended only for the named recipient(s) and may be subject to attorney-client and/or work product privileges; if received in error, the recipient should notify the sender and destroy the email.

Earlier in the thread, Aaron Whaley responded to the request with, “yes, that’s fine.” His reply was sent on the same day, June 25, 2024, at 13:15:33 -0400, and was directed to Bryce Koon, Deanna M. Tucker, and Sarena Tuttle. Aaron’s signature established his firm as the Whaley Law Firm, with a mailing address at 712 Lyndon Ln, Louisville, KY 40222, and a contact phone number of 502-583-4022. The To field on Aaron’s reply included the three recipients listed above, and there was no entry in the CC field.

Tucker to Aaron Whaley, with copies sent to Bryce Koon, Sarena Tuttle, Kristy M. King, and Matthew Londergan. The email is dated Monday, August 19, 2024 at 22:25:58 +0000. Marzian Tucker, Partner, with the same Louisville address (401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202) and direct contact numbers (Direct Phone: 502.625.1671; Direct Fax: 502.779.9329), and it included the same confidentiality disclaimer.

episodes.original_body:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ BK Attended MTC Motion Hour - Judge granted DC Vilches 21 Days to Respond - Sent update to Client via Text:

Good afternoon Schrice,
We just wanted to update you that we are still awaiting the Defendant's Response to our Discovery Requests. The Responses are overdue and Bryce did file a Motion to Compel the Responses. That Motion was heard today & the Judge is allowing the Defense 21 days to Respond. Their new deadline is October 14, 2024 per the Judge. We anticipate they may be respond sooner than the deadline, but will keep you posted as things progress. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm
Posted by you on 9/23/2024 at 12:45 PM Delivered 
__Person Making Contact:__ Sarena
__Date & Time__: September 23 2024

Castillo matter, with cc to Sarena at Whaley Law Firm and to the Sariya Mason Filevine project email address. The subject line read “Re: FW: Thomas v. Castillo.” In the body, Bryce stated that the video in question was presumably included in a link sent previously, but that, if not, the video should be accessible via the link provided: https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/sctz3bcvybirwnoa3dzee/Video-Footage-of-Attack.mp4?rlkey=8rlc4qwrszszm4bduq2jtk6bm&st=rk7uyx2n&dl=0. The email also contained The Whaley Law Firm’s standard confidentiality notice, stating that the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney-client or work product information; recipients who receive it in error should contact the firm and not disclose its contents.

Earlier the same day, at 2:57 PM, Karen S. Wolford forwarded an email with the subject “Thomas v. Castillo” to AGWhaley@WhaleyLawFirm.com. In that message, Karen wrote: “Counsel – Good afternoon. Can you please send me the video from Plaintiff’s Ring camera? Thank you.” Karen’s message included her professional title as Paralegal and her contact information: 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502.625.1681; Direct Fax: 502.779.9339. This email also carried the Confidentiality Notice common to the correspondence.

At approximately 2:58 PM on September 25, 2024, Karen S. Wolford replied, noting, “I apologize, I meant to include you all on the below email. Thanks.” The reply appears to address the distribution of the prior message and to confirm additional recipients. The thread, including the original message from Karen at 2:57 PM and subsequent replies, includes Karen’s signature block and the standard confidentiality disclaimer.

episodes.natural_language: Initial client contact on October 14, 2024, in the Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022 matter. Bryce spoke with Shrice and explained that they have not responded to our discovery and that today is the deadline from MTC. Bryce explained that he would be calling them shortly to follow up and would demand 25k for a full settlement in lieu of further litigation. He told Shrice that he was not sure where they stood or if they would put any more money on it, but it’s worth a shot at this point. Shrice understood and agreed.

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. This note records a series of communications concerning the Thomas v. Castillo matter, with the Whaley Law Firm acting on behalf of the client in Kentucky.

On November 20, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial 502-357-9971; office 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note the new email address), sent an email to Kristy M. King regarding the Supplemental Discovery in the Thomas v. Castillo matter. She stated that the Supplemental Discovery had originally been served on October 18, 2024 and referenced attached email correspondence for further reference. She explained that while she understood Mrs. Tucker’s trial commitments, she could grant an extension only to November 29, 2024, and that any additional time would require approval from the attorneys. She noted that she had added the attorneys to the email chain for their review of the extension request and offered to discuss any further needs.

Earlier in the chain, on November 19, 2024, Kristy M. King, Legal Assistant at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, KY 40202 (direct phone 502-625-1706; direct fax 502-583-4780), wrote in reply (times noted in the thread as 3:46?PM): “Received, thank you.” She indicated that Ms. Tucker was not able to locate the email showing when the supplemental discovery had been sent to her and asked Sarena to confirm the date of service. Kristy also noted that Ms. Tucker was in trial that week and requested an extension for these responses, asking whether December 6 would be agreeable. The message included the standard confidentiality notice.

The thread also shows an earlier message from Kristy M. King titled “Thomas v. Castillo,” sent at 7:49?AM on November 19, 2024, to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com and bryce@whaleylawfirm.com. In that message, she requested a copy of the supplemental discovery requests that accompany the attached Notice of Service, stating that she had not received a copy. A forwarded message from Aaron Whaley then appears in the chain, followed by Kristy’s signature block.

Additionally, on November 19, 2024 at 3:35 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied to Kristy: “Good afternoon Kristy, Please find attached the Word & PDF versions of the requested documents. If you need anything else, please do not hesitate to contact us.” This message included Sarena’s signature with her title and contact information and again noted the new email address.

Attached materials in the thread included Word and PDF versions of the requested documents, and the correspondence lists the parties in the chain as well as the CCs: Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon. The email chain also included confidentiality notices in the body of the messages.

In sum, the record shows that Supplemental Discovery was first served on October 18, 2024; an extension to November 29, 2024 was granted by Sarena Tuttle, with further extension beyond that requiring attorney approval. Kristy King sought confirmation of the service date and proposed December 6, 2024 as an additional extension due to Ms. Tucker’s trial schedule, while also requesting a copy of the supplemental discovery requests that accompany the Notice of Service, which had not been received. The thread includes multiple copies of attachments (Word and PDF) and standard confidentiality notices.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. Re: Thomas v. Castillo. This sequence documents the email communications among the Whaley Law Firm and SBMKYLaw regarding supplemental discovery in the Thomas v. Castillo matter, within the Sariya Mason file, including dates, extensions, and the exchange of documents.

On November 19, 2024, at 7:49 a.m., Kristy M. King, a Legal Assistant at SBMKY Law, sent an email to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com and bryce@whaleylawfirm.com with the subject Thomas v. Castillo. She requested a copy of the supplemental discovery requests that accompany the attached Notice of Service, noting that she had not received a copy herself. Her message began with a cordial “Good Morning” and included her contact details: 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone: 502.625.1706; Direct Fax: 502.583.4780.

That same day, a forwarded copy of Kristy King’s request was sent in an email from Aaron Whaley within the Whaley Law Firm to his colleagues, reflecting the ongoing exchange about the Thomas v. Castillo matter and confirming that Kristy had not received the supplemental discovery requests.

Later that day, at 3:35 p.m., Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Kristy. She stated, “Please find attached the Word & PDF versions of the requested documents. If you need anything else, please do not hesitate to contact us.” Her message confirmed that the Word and PDF versions of the requested documents had been attached. The signature block identified her at The Whaley Law Firm, with the firm’s Louisville address and contact information, and reminded recipients to note her new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

On November 19, 2024, at 3:46 p.m., Kristy M. King responded: “Received, thank you. Ms. Tucker was not able to locate the email for when these were sent to her, can you confirm the date of service for me? Ms. Tucker is in trial this week and we will need to request an extension on these responses, would December 6th be agreeable?” Kristy’s message reiterated the need to confirm the service date and proposed a December 6 extension deadline, given her client’s trial schedule. Her message included her standard SBMKY Law contact details and confidentiality notice.

The email chain shows that Sarena’s earlier note from November 20, 2024, at approximately 10:02 a.m., referenced the supplemental discovery originally served on October 18, 2024. In that communication, Sarena attached the relevant email correspondence for reference. She explained that while they understood Mrs. Tucker’s trial commitments, she could grant an extension to November 29, 2024, with any additional extension requiring approval by the attorneys involved. She stated she had added the attorneys to the chain to review the extension request and invited further discussion if needed.

Finally, on December 2, 2024, Sarena wrote to Kristy again: “Good afternoon Kristy, We just wanted to touch base with you on these Responses, any update would be greatly appreciated.” She signed as the Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm and provided her contact information, reiterating the note about her new email address.

Across the thread, the participants included Kristy M. King of SBMKYLaw, Deanna Tucker (also at SBMKYLaw), and senior firm members Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon, all copied on various messages. The communications center on obtaining and confirming the date of service for the supplemental discovery requests related to Thomas v. Castillo, the need for extensions due to trial schedules, and the provision of Word and PDF versions of the requested documents. The case note remains within the Sariya Mason file (Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022) and pertains to the Thomas v. Castillo matter, with new contact details noted for Sarena Tuttle.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. Re: Thomas v. Castillo.

On December 2, 2024, Deanna M. Tucker, a partner at SBMKY Law, sent an email to Sarena Tuttle and Kristy M. King with Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon CC’ed. In her message, she said she hoped Sarena was well and noted that Friday had apparently been a court holiday, adding that they would serve “these” that day. She signed as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, Partner, and provided her office address—401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202—as well as her direct phone number (502.625.1671) and direct fax (502.779.9329). The email footer also included a confidentiality notice stating the communication is intended only for the named recipients and may be subject to attorney-client and/or work product privileges; if received in error, the recipient should notify the sender and destroy the email. The signature line identified her as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker.

Earlier that same day, at 2:17 PM, Sarena Tuttle replied to Kristy King and Deanna Tucker, with Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon CC’ed, asking for an update on “these Responses.” Her message also included her contact information, noting a new email address for herself: Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct and office numbers and the email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com.

The thread contains a longer history of communications preceding that December 2 exchange. On November 20, 2024 (time indicated as 10:02 AM, though the exact minutes are unclear in the record), Sarena wrote that the Supplemental Discovery had originally been served on October 18, 2024. She referenced attached email correspondence for further reference, acknowledged Mrs. Tucker’s trial-related situation, and stated that she could grant an extension to November 29, 2024; any additional extension would require approval by the attorneys. She noted that she had added the attorneys to the chain for review of the extension request and invited further discussion if needed.

Earlier, on November 19, 2024, at 3:46 PM, Kristy M. King replied: She had received the prior message and confirmed that Ms. Tucker was not able to locate the email showing when the supplemental discovery had been sent. She asked Kristy to confirm the date of service and indicated that Ms. Tucker would be in trial that week and that they would need to request an extension on the responses, proposing December 6 as an agreeable date.

Kristy’s message was followed by a November 19, 2024, 3:35 PM response from Sarena: “Please find attached the Word & PDF versions of the requested documents. If you need anything else, please do not hesitate to contact us.” This message was signed by Sarena M. Tuttle with the same Whaley Law Firm contact details and again noted the new email address.

Earlier still, at 10:38 AM on November 19, 2024, Aaron Whaley forwarded a message from Kristy M. King. In Kristy’s earlier note, dated November 19, 2024 at 7:49 AM, she addressed the matter to agwhaley@whaleylawfirm.com and bryce@whaleylawfirm.com and asked: “Good Morning, would you please send me a copy of the supplemental discovery requests that go with the attached Notice of Service? I never received a copy.” Kristy included her own contact information and a confidentiality notice in her signature.

The chain concludes with Aaron Whaley’s signature block after Kristy’s initial request.

In summary, this case involves the Thomas v. Castillo matter in which supplemental discovery was served October 18, 2024, with ongoing discussions in November 2024 about extensions due to trial schedules. On December 2, 2024, Deanna Tucker indicated they would serve the documents that day, and Sarena Tuttle sought updates regarding the responses. The communications reveal multiple parties coordinating service, requesting and granting extensions (noting a tentative extension to November 29, 2024, and the possibility of additional extensions subject to attorney approval), and sharing attachments of the Word and PDF versions of the requested documents. The thread also establishes new contact details for Sarena Tuttle (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) and reiterates confidentiality provisions present in each email.
