episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Thomas v. Castillo, within the Sariya-Mason file (Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022) for client Sariya Mason, an email chain in late November and early December 2024 covered discovery responses and extension requests. The primary participants were Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm; Deanna M. Tucker, Partner at SBM Kentucky Law; Kristy M. King, Legal Assistant at SBM Kentucky Law; and colleagues Aaron Whaley and Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm.

On December 2, 2024, at 3:12 PM, Sarena sent a note to Deanna Tucker with copies to Kristy King and others, acknowledging an extension request that had been noted for December 6. Sarena stated she could grant only a two-week extension, which would fall on a holiday Friday, and she expressed understanding that papers would not be received on that day. She closed by noting her new contact information.

Earlier that same day, at 2:57 PM, Deanna Tucker replied, acknowledging that Friday had been a court holiday and indicating that they would serve the documents that day. The message included Deanna’s standard contact details and confidentiality notice.

Also on December 2, at 2:17 PM, Sarena followed up with Kristy King (and Deanna Tucker), asking for an update on the responses and inviting further discussion if needed.

Looking back, on November 20, 2024, Sarena had written that the Supplemental Discovery was originally served on October 18, 2024. She referenced attached email correspondence for context and explained that, while she understood Deanna Tucker’s trial commitments, she could grant an extension to November 29, 2024, with any additional time requiring approval from the attorneys. She added the attorneys to the email chain for review of the extension request.

Earlier, on November 19, 2024, Kristy King replied that she had received the prior message and noted that Deanna Tucker had been unable to locate the email showing when the materials were sent; Kristy asked for confirmation of the date of service and suggested that, given Tucker’s trial schedule, they would need to request an extension and asked whether December 6 would be agreeable.

That same day, November 19, at 3:35 PM, Sarena responded to Kristy, attaching Word and PDF versions of the requested documents and inviting any further needs.

At 10:38 AM on November 19, 2024, Aaron Whaley forwarded a message from Kristy King requesting a copy of the supplemental discovery requests that accompany the attached Notice of Service, noting that she had not received a copy. Kristy’s message included her contact details and a confidentiality disclaimer.

Kristy King’s earlier message, sent at 7:49 AM on November 19, 2024, had asked for a copy of the supplemental discovery requests that go with the attached Notice of Service, stating that she never received them. Aaron Whaley then forwarded Kristy’s request into the chain, with contact information for himself and Bryce Koon.

Across these exchanges, the parties discussed service dates, potential extensions (including a proposed December 6 extension), the need for attorney approval for extensions beyond November 29, 2024, and the provision of Word and PDF copies of the requested discovery documents. The chain also included confidentiality notices typical of communications among the firms.

episodes.natural_language:
Initial client contact on December 2, 2024, with Sarena regarding case Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022 for client Sariya Mason. A guardian call was received, and the guardian provided an update: the defense counsel’s response to the supplemental discovery request will be served today per DC, and the deposition schedule will be reviewed later this week.

Ms. Mason expressed understanding and was informed that the defendants appear to have moved from their residence; it cannot be confirmed whether they merely moved or moved out of the United States. I advised that DC is on the hook to produce the defendants for deposition at this point; their moving does not change the claim. Insurance will be responsible for payment of a settlement when obtained. The client stated that she feels better knowing that her moving does not affect the claim.

This matter concerns Case Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022, involving client Sariya Mason, captioned as Thomas v. Castillo.

On December 12, 2024, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Deanna M. Tucker, Esq., with a copy to the Sariya Mason Filevine project email address. He advised counsel to see the attached Motion to Compel, noting that the motion had been set for motion hour on Monday, January 6, 2025. He stated that if his client’s verified responses were received by that date, he would be happy to remand the motion. The email included Mr. Koon’s contact information and a confidentiality disclaimer indicating the message is intended only for the named recipient and may contain attorney‑client privileged material; recipients who received it in error should contact The Whaley Law Firm and not use or forward the information.

Earlier in the chain, on Wednesday, December 4, 2024 at 1:46? PM, Bryce Koon wrote to counsel: “Good afternoon counsel, We are in receipt of your responses. However, it appears that only the Requests for Admissions were answered. Please advise when we may receive answers to the related interrogatories and document request.” This message also carried Mr. Koon’s signature block and the same confidentiality notice.

Prior to that, on Monday, December 2, 2024 at 6:56? PM, Deanna M. Tucker responded. Her signature identifies her as Deanna M. Marzian Tucker, Partner, with offices at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202. Her direct phone number is 502.625.1671 and direct fax is 502.779.9329. The message also included the firm’s logo description and a confidentiality notice stating that the communication and any attached files are intended only for the named recipients and may be privileged; if received in error, the recipient should notify the sender and destroy the communication.

Throughout these exchanges, the electronic messages carried standard confidentiality notices instructing recipients not to use or forward the information if received in error. The December 12, 2024 email also listed a CC to the Sariya Mason Filevine project email address, SariyaMasonZ2040607@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com. The communications were all about the Motion to Compel and the status of discovery responses, including admissions, interrogatories, and documents.

Sarena Tuttle replied on the same day at 2:57 PM, acknowledging receipt and indicating that, upon initial review, there was reference to a recording from Leandry Badia, but she had not actually received any recording. She pointed out that the Response to the Request for Production indicated the recording had been previously provided, yet it did not appear to be attached to the initial production file, and she asked that a copy of the alleged recording be forwarded for review. Her signature also notes that she is a Litigation Paralegal & Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm and includes her new email address.

A hard copy will not follow unless requested.” This message was followed by Londergan’s standard confidentiality notice.

King, and Deanna M. Tucker) concerning Thomas v. Castillo. Smith’s message header identifies his firm’s contact details: Barnes Maloney PLLC, 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; email bsmith@sbmkylaw.com; direct phone 502.625.1674; direct fax 502.779.9326; mobile 502.553.5258; website www.sbmkylaw.com. Case note for Sariya Mason (Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022) documents correspondence connected to the Jefferson Circuit Court action Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al., case number 23-CI-006039. The record also lists a Filevine project email for Sariya Mason: SariyaMasonZ2040607@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com.

On February 4, 2025 at 10:01:04 AM (GMT-05:00), W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email from bryce@whaleylawfirm.com to opposing counsel Deanna Tucker, Kristy M. King, and Matthew Londergan, with Sarena Tuttle and the Sariya Mason Filevine contact CC’d. The message stated that the attached filing had been filed that day and was set for next Monday’s motion hour. It included Bryce Koon’s signature and the firm’s contact information, along with the standard attorney-client privilege disclaimer noting that the message is intended only for the named recipient and instructing recipients who received it in error to contact the sender and not to forward the information.

Earlier in the chain, on January 9, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, wrote that, after reviewing the file, all written discovery appeared completed and/or near completion. She stated the intention to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Vilches as soon as possible and asked for dates in which both counsel and their client would be available. Because Mrs. Vilches’ native language is not English, she requested that a translator be scheduled and asked that the recipient confirm Mrs. Vilches’ native dialect to ensure the best translator could be arranged. This message carried the Whaley Law Firm signature block and confidentiality disclaimer.

On January 17, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle sent another message to counsel requesting deposition dates for Mrs. Vilches and noting that Mrs. Vilches speaks some derivative of Spanish. She requested confirmation of her native language to avoid further delays, emphasized that the claim is over 2.5 years old and includes video footage of the incident showing an unprovoked attack, and suggested that a Zoom deposition may be the best option given that defense clients reportedly leave the United States to visit family, though Zoom is not ideal. She invited direct contact to discuss the matter further and again provided her Whaley Law Firm contact information and new email address.

On January 24, 2025 at approximately 12:24 PM, Bryce Koon replied that they were again seeking deposition dates for the client’s deposition and requested dates in February or March for when such depositions could be conducted. The message included the standard confidentiality disclaimer typical of the firm’s communications.

Throughout these exchanges, the messages included the Whaley Law Firm’s standard attorney-client privilege notices and instructions regarding misdelivery. The chronology reflects ongoing efforts to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Vilches, address language translation needs, and coordinate dates for depositions in the Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al. matter, all while managing the related Sariya Mason case file.

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. This note concerns the matter Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al., in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-006039.

On February 4, 2025, at 10:01:04 a.m. Eastern Time, W. Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (billing address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; phone 502-365-5043; fax 502-237-3207) sent an email to Deanna Tucker, Kristy M. King, and Matthew Londergan, with Sarena Tuttle and the Sariya Mason Filevine project email address copied on the message. The subject line referenced the Schrice Thomas matter. In the body, Bryce stated: “Good morning counsel, Please see attached filed today and set for next Monday's motion hour. If you have any questions in this regard, please let me know.” He signed as W. Bryce Koon, Esq., and included the standard firm closing with contact information. He also attached the customary attorney-client privilege disclaimer, noting that the electronic message is intended only for the named recipient and that if received in error, the recipient should contact The Whaley Law Firm, there is no waiver of privilege, and the information should not be used or forwarded to any non‑intended recipient.

Earlier in the thread, there were additional communications beginning January 9, 2025. On January 9, 2025, at 2:03 p.m. (time shown as 2:03?PM in the header), Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote that, upon review of the file, all written discovery had been completed and/or was near completion. The firm wished to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Vilches as soon as possible and asked for dates when both opposing counsel and their client would be available. Because Mrs. Vilches’ native language is not English, they would need to schedule a translator and requested that opposing counsel confirm Mrs. Vilches’ native dialogue to ensure the best translator could be arranged. The email included Tuttle’s contact details and noted her new email address.

On January 17, 2025, at 2:22 p.m. (time shown as 2:22?PM), Sarena Tuttle wrote again. She stated they were trying to obtain deposition dates for Mrs. Vilches and noted that Mrs. Vilches speaks some derivative of Spanish; they requested confirmation of Mrs. Vilches’ native language as well. Tuttle urged providing this information as soon as possible to avoid further delays, emphasizing that the claim is over 2.5 years old and includes video footage of the incident showing an unprovoked attack. She added that counsel’s clients tend to leave the United States to visit family and suggested that a Zoom deposition might be best, though not ideal, and invited direct contact to discuss further.

On January 24, 2025, at approximately 12:24 p.m. (time shown as 12:24?PM), Bryce Koon again wrote to counsel. He stated that they were “again attempting to obtain dates for your client’s depositions” and requested dates in February or March when those depositions could be conducted. This message also carried The Whaley Law Firm’s standard privilege disclaimer, indicating the message was for the named recipient, may contain privileged information, and advising that if received in error, the recipient should contact the firm and not disclose or forward the contents.

Throughout these emails, the standard electronic-communications disclaimers were included in each message, noting privilege and the intended recipient, with instructions for recipients who may have received the message in error to contact The Whaley Law Firm and not use or forward the information.

Additional details in the January thread show that Sarena M. Tuttle’s messages carried her role and contact information, including her extension (D: 502-357-9971; O: 502-583-4022 ext 104) and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with an explicit note that the address is their new email. The messages repeatedly reference the same case and the scheduling of depositions for Mrs. Vilches, along with concerns about language barriers, the need for translators, and potential Zoom deposition arrangements given travel considerations.

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. The matter at issue is Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al, in Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-006039. The notes reflect a series of emails between The Whaley Law Firm and SBMKylaw.com regarding depositions for Mrs. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo in this case, with Sariya Mason listed in the file as of 08/19/2022 (Filevine project email address: SariyaMasonZ2040607@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com).

Starting January 9, 2025, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote to counsel recommending that the deposition of Mrs. Vilches be scheduled as soon as possible. She noted that Mrs. Vilches’s native language is something other than English and requested confirmation of Mrs. Vilches’s native dialogue to ensure the scheduling of an appropriate translator. She also highlighted that the claim is over 2.5 years old and that video footage exists showing an unprovoked attack, and she suggested that a Zoom deposition might be best if travel proves difficult. The message was signed with Sarena M. Tuttle’s contact information, including the note “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

On January 17, 2025, Sarena followed up again with counsel, indicating the need to obtain deposition dates for Mrs. Vilches and reiterating that Mrs. Vilches speaks some derivative of Spanish and that confirmation of her native language was required to arrange an appropriate translator. She urged providing information promptly to avoid further delays in a case where the parties may be traveling since they tend to leave the United States to visit family, and she again suggested a Zoom deposition as a possible, though less ideal, option.

A January 24, 2025 email from Bryce Koon, Esq., of The Whaley Law Firm (sent to Deanna M. Tucker, Kristy M. King, and Matthew Londergan, with Sarena Tuttle and Sariya Mason DB cc’d) reiterated the ongoing effort to obtain deposition dates for the clients. Bryce requested dates in February or March for the depositions. The message included the standard confidentiality language common to these communications and provided Bryce Koon’s firm contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; Phone: (502) 365-5043; Fax: (502) 237-3207. An image was attached, and the email contained the firm’s confidentiality notice, stating that the communication is intended only for the named recipient and that privilege may apply.

On February 7, 2025, Matthew R. Londergan, Attorney at SBMKylaw, replied to Bryce and others. He listed available deposition dates for February and March: Thursday, February 20 after 11 a.m.; Thursday, March 6 at any time; Thursday, March 13 at any time; and Thursday, March 27 at any time. He confirmed that a Spanish interpreter would be needed for these depositions. He invited the other side to indicate if any dates did not work so that additional dates could be provided, noting that Thursdays generally work best for their clients.

By February 10, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle responded with a proposed timing for the depositions. She proposed that on March 6, 2025, beginning at 10:00 a.m., the deposition with Mrs. Vilches would occur first, followed by the deposition with Mrs. Castillo in the afternoon, or vice versa. She asked whether their office could be used for the convenience of the parties. The message was signed by Sarena with the same contact details and again included the notice to use the new email address. The note also lists The Whaley Law Firm’s address and contact lines, and reiterates the ongoing coordination among the counsel and the clients in the Jeff Cir Crt case 23-CI-006039.

In summary, the communications between The Whaley Law Firm and SBMKylaw between January and February 2025 centered on scheduling the depositions of Mrs. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo in the Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al matter, with emphasis on obtaining Spanish-language interpretation, the possibility of Zoom participation, and leveraging counsel’s offices for convenience on March 6, 2025, beginning at 10:00 a.m.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. The matter at hand is Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al, in Jeff Cir Court, case number 23-CI-006039. The file concerns deposition planning for Mrs. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo, in support of the underlying claim involving Sariya Mason.

On January 9, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, wrote that, after reviewing the file, all written discovery had been completed and/or was near completion. She stated a deposition of Mrs. Vilches should be scheduled as soon as possible and asked for dates on which both counsel and their clients would be available. Because Mrs. Vilches’ native language is not English, she requested confirmation of Mrs. Vilches’ native dialogue to ensure the scheduling of an appropriate translator.

On January 17, 2025, Sarena followed up, noting that deposition dates for Mrs. Vilches were still needed and requesting confirmation of the language details. She emphasized that the claim was over 2.5 years old and included video footage of the incident showing an unprovoked attack. She also indicated that a Zoom deposition might be best, though not ideal, and asked to discuss any questions directly to avoid further delays.

On January 24, 2025, Bryce Koon, Esq., with The Whaley Law Firm, replied to Deanna Tucker, Kristy King, Matthew Londergan, and others, stating that counsel was again attempting to obtain deposition dates for the clients and requesting dates in February or March for when the depositions could be conducted. The message included Bryce’s contact information and a note referencing the Sariya Mason file: “Sariya Mason DB 08/19/2022 - Filevine Project Email Address <SariyaMasonZ2040607@louisvilleaccidentlawyer.filevineapp.com>.”

On February 7, 2025, Matthew R. Londergan, Attorney, responded with available dates: Thursday, February 20 after 11 a.m.; Thursday, March 6, any time; Thursday, March 13, any time; and Thursday, March 27, any time. He confirmed that both clients are available on those dates and noted that a Spanish interpreter would be required for the depositions. He asked to be notified if any of these dates did not work to obtain additional options, and he observed that Thursdays generally work best for their clients.

On February 10, 2025, Sarena replied that March 6, 2025, beginning at 10:00 a.m., with Mrs. Vilches, and continuing with Mrs. Castillo in the afternoon or vice versa, would work for their office. She asked whether they could use Matthew’s office for the depositions to facilitate the proceedings. In a prior related exchange, Sarena had requested confirmation of Mrs. Vilches’ language to arrange translation accordingly.

That same day, February 10, 2025, at 10:24 a.m. (the exact time is shown as 10:24?AM in the record), Matthew responded that the conference room at their office would be available on that day and that the depositions could proceed in whichever order the parties preferred. Later that day, at 11:04 a.m., Sarena replied, “Awesome, sounds great. We will get a notice over to you & the court reporter today.”

Throughout the correspondence, standard confidentiality notices accompany the messages, reiterating privileges and instructing recipients to notify the sender if a message was received in error. The records also show various contact details for the participants, including Sarena Tuttle’s address at The Whaley Law Firm in Louisville, KY, with direct lines and her new email address, and Matthew Londergan’s office address and direct lines. The exchange also references the ongoing need for a Spanish interpreter and the logistics of arranging depositions for Mrs. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo, with a preference for using the office of Matthew Londergan for convenience.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al., Jefferson Circuit Court Case 23-CI-006039, the depositions of the witnesses were coordinated across a long email thread in early 2025. The client listed in the structured file is Sariya Mason (case file: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022). The thread shows ongoing discussions between The Whaley Law Firm and SBMKY Law about scheduling depositions for Ms. Thomas and Ms. Mason, with a particular focus on the witnesses Mrs. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo, and with a Spanish interpreter required.

The exchange began with an email from January 9, 2025. Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, asked Matthew Londergan, an attorney at SBMKY Law, to schedule the deposition of Mrs. Vilches as soon as possible. She requested confirmation of Mrs. Vilches’s native language to ensure an appropriate translator could be arranged, noting that the language was not English and that scheduling would hinge on identifying the best translator for Mrs. Vilches.

On January 17, 2025, Sarena followed up, indicating that March 6, 2025, beginning at 10:00 a.m., would work for her office for the deposition of Mrs. Vilches, with the deposition of Mrs. Castillo to follow in the afternoon or vice versa. She also suggested using SBMKY’s office for the convenience of the parties and asked for confirmation of the native language to ensure proper translation arrangements. Her message also referenced that the claim in question is more than two and a half years old and included video footage of the incident, described as an unprovoked attack, underscoring the time sensitivity of scheduling and translation needs.

On January 24, 2025, Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm emailed counsel, reiterating the need to obtain deposition dates and requesting dates in February or March for both sides’ clients. He CC’d Sarena Tuttle and included Sariya Mason’s filehouse contact as part of the Filevine project.

On February 7, 2025, Matthew Londergan replied to Bryce, listing several potential dates: Thursday, February 20 after 11 a.m.; Thursday, March 6 (any time); Thursday, March 13 (any time); and Thursday, March 27 (any time). He noted that both clients would require a Spanish interpreter and welcomed additional date suggestions if these did not work, adding that Thursdays generally work best for their clients.

The thread continued on February 9 and February 10, 2025, with further scheduling details. On February 10 at 9:46 a.m., Sarena Tuttle responded that March 6, 2025, beginning at 10:00 a.m., would work for her office for the deposition of Mrs. Vilches, with Mrs. Castillo to be scheduled for the afternoon or vice versa. She asked whether SBMKY would allow the deposition to be held at The Whaley Law Firm’s office for the convenience of the parties and reiterated the need to confirm Mrs. Vilches’s native language to arrange a translator.

Shortly after, at 10:24 a.m. on February 10, Matthew Londergan confirmed that the conference room at SBMKY’s office would be available on that day and that the deposition order could be arranged to suit the parties’ preferences. He indicated that the depositions could be conducted in SBMKY’s conference room and that the order of the two depositions could be arranged to accommodate the witnesses.

Later on February 10, 2025, at 11:04 a.m., Sarena wrote that she would send a notice to both the opposing counsel and the court reporter that day. She reaffirmed the confidentiality of the communication, as did the standard notices that accompanied the email chain.

Finally, at 4:16 p.m. (UTC) on February 10, 2025, Matthew Londergan sent a concluding note reiterating the request to schedule the depositions within the same timeframe and asking Sarena to provide dates in March or April when Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason could be available. He closed with his standard attorney signature block, including his office address at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202, direct phone number 502.625.1678, and direct fax 502.779.9336.

Throughout these correspondences, confidentiality notices were included in each message, reminding recipients that the communications and any attachments are intended for the named parties and may be privileged. The exchanges show a collaborative effort to coordinate two depositions (Ms. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo) in the JeffCir Crt case, with a strong emphasis on securing a Spanish interpreter and choosing a scheduling window that aligns with both sides’ availability in March and April, ideally within SBMKY’s conference room for convenience. The Whaley Law Firm’s contact details were consistently provided, including Sarena Tuttle’s role as a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager, and her new email address.

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter titled Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al, Jeff Cir Court, case number 23-CI-006039, the Whaley Law Firm's file for Sariya Mason (case noted as Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022) documents communications between The Whaley Law Firm and SBM KY Law regarding scheduling depositions. The client listed is Sariya Mason.

On February 10, 2025, at 11:23:12 a.m. Eastern Time, Sarena Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Matthew Londergan of SBM KY Law. In that message, she wrote: “Absolutely, Mr. Londergan, Please find attached the NTTD for the Defendant's Depositions. We have requested a Spanish Translator for that day as well. I have sent a request to Mrs. Thomas & Sariya to check when they can be available. I will update you as soon as I hear back.” Her signature noted her contact details, including her new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky address and telephone numbers.

Earlier that same day, at 11:16 a.m., Matthew R. Londergan replied: “Sarena: We would like to get your clients’ depositions scheduled in the same timeframe, if possible. Would you please send us some dates that Ms. Thomas and Sariya are available in March/April?” He provided his contact information, including 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, Kentucky 40202; Direct Phone 502.625.1678; Direct Fax 502.779.9336.

At 11:04 a.m. on February 10, Sarena responded: “Awesome, sounds great. We will get a notice over to you & the court reporter today.” This message, like others, included her Whaley Law Firm header and contact details.

Earlier on February 10, at 10:24 a.m., Matthew Londergan had noted that the conference room at his office would be available that day and that Whaley could decide the order of deposition proceedings. He stated: “Whichever order you all would prefer to do the depositions in is fine with us.”

At 9:46 a.m. on February 10, Sarena wrote: “Good morning Matthew, March 6, 2025 beginning at 10:00a with Mrs. Vilches and continuing with Mrs. Castillo in the afternoon or vice versa, works for our office. Do you mind if we use your office for the convenience of the parties?” This message again carried the standard firm signature block.

On February 7, 2025, at 3:38 p.m., Matthew Londergan had previously replied to Bryce Koon: “Bryce: Sorry for the delay in getting back to you on this. Both of our clients are available on any of the following dates: Thursday, February 20 after 11 a.m.; Thursday, March 6, any time; Thursday, March 13, any time; Thursday, March 27, any time. We have confirmed that we will need a Spanish interpreter for these depositions. Let me know if these dates do not work for you, and we will obtain some more possible dates. In talking to our clients, Thursdays generally work best.” His note included his contact details.

On January 24, 2025 at 12:25 p.m., Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm sent an email to Deanna M. Tucker, Kristy M. King, and Matthew Londergan, with Sariya Mason DB in the CC line and a Filevine project email address associated with Sariya Mason. The subject line referenced the same case. Bryce wrote: “Good afternoon counsel, We are again attempting to obtain dates for your client's depositions. Please provide dates in February or March for when these can be conducted. Thank you, W. Bryce Koon, Esq.” His signature block provided the firm’s address and contact information, including the phone number (502) 365-5043 and fax number (502) 237-3207. An image attachment note appeared, with a standard confidentiality disclaimer stating the message is intended only for the named recipient and advising recipients to contact The Whaley Law Firm if received in error.

Earlier still, on January 17, 2025, at 2:22 p.m., Sarena Tuttle wrote to counsel: “Good afternoon Counsel, We just wanted to touch base again on getting deposition dates for Mrs. Vilches, we understand that Mrs. Vilches speaks some derivative of Spanish and would like confirmation of her native language as well. Please provide this information as soon as possible to avoid any further delays as this claim is over 2.5 years old with video footage of the incident, showing an unprovoked attack. We further understand that your clients tend to leave the United States to visit family, and that a Zoom deposition may be best, though not ideal.” The note ends mid-sentence with “If you,” indicating that the message was truncated. The thread included the same confidentiality notices commonly attached to transmissions of that firm.

In summary, the communications between The Whaley Law Firm and SBM KY Law from mid-January to early February 2025 focused on scheduling depositions for the parties involved in Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al., establishing that a Spanish interpreter would be required, arranging dates (with a preference for Thursdays), and coordinating the use of either counsel’s office to facilitate the depositions. The deposition targets include Mrs. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo, with arrangements involving Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason as named deponents, and a Spanish translator to be provided for those proceedings.

episodes.natural_language:
Case overview: This note concerns the Sariya Mason client (Sariya Mason, DB 08/19/2022) in Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al.,Jefferson Circuit Court, case number 23-CI-006039.

Chronology of communications:

- January 24, 2025: Bryce Koon, Esq., on behalf of The Whaley Law Firm, emailed Deanna M. Tucker, Kristy M. King, Matthew Londergan, and others (including a Filevine project address for Sariya Mason) requesting dates in February or March for the depositions. The message was a general follow-up requesting deposition dates.

- February 7, 2025, 3:38 PM: Matthew R. Londergan, attorney, replied with potential deposition dates for both clients: Thursday, February 20 after 11 a.m.; Thursday, March 6 any time; Thursday, March 13 any time; Thursday, March 27 any time. He noted that a Spanish interpreter would be required for these depositions and invited Bryce to advise if these dates did not work to obtain additional options, adding that Thursdays generally work best for their clients.

- February 9, 2025, 9:46 AM: Sarena M. Tuttle, litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, responded to Matthew. She proposed March 6, 2025 beginning at 10:00 a.m. with Mrs. Vilches and continuing with Mrs. Castillo in the afternoon or vice versa, and asked consent to use the firm’s office for the convenience of the parties.

- February 10, 2025, 10:24 AM: Matthew replied that the conference room at their office would be available that day and that the depositions could proceed in either order.

- February 10, 2025, 11:04 AM: Sarena responded, “Awesome, sounds great. We will get a notice over to you & the court reporter today,” confirming next steps.

- February 10, 2025, 11:16 AM: Matthew followed up, stating the desire to schedule the depositions for both clients in the same timeframe and requesting that Sarena send dates when Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available in March/April.

- February 10, 2025, 11:23 AM: Sarena sent a reply with the NTTD (Notice to Take Deposition) for the Defendant’s Depositions attached. She noted that a Spanish translator had been requested and that she had sent a request to Mrs. Thomas and Sariya to check availability, promising to provide an update once responses were received.

- February 11, 2025, 4:21 PM (UTC): Matthew Londergan sent an update indicating new scheduling constraints: they had learned that Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, but Ms. Castillo would still be available that day. To accommodate either schedule, he proposed that, if the parties preferred to depose both witnesses on the same day, both Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo would be available at any time on one of the following alternative dates: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, or March 27. He also confirmed that a conference room at their office would be available for the depositions on any of these dates. If none of these dates work for the opponent, they would pursue dates in April. He closed by inviting a call to discuss further.

Other notes and identifiers:
- The case caption remains Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al., Jeff Cir Court, 23-CI-006039.
- The client involved in this matter is Sariya Mason (DB 08/19/2022).
- The parties identified for deposition include Ms. Vilches, Ms. Castillo, and involvement of Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason.
- A Spanish interpreter is required for these depositions.
- The depositions were proposed to be held at the Whaley Law Firm office, with a conference room reserved for convenience.
- The communications included a series of confirmations, notices to court reporters, and requests to check availability, with a standing offer to adjust dates into April if needed.
- Contact details for the participants include:
  - Matthew R. Londergan, Attorney, 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, KY 40202. Direct Phone: 502.625.1678; Direct Fax: 502.779.9336.
  - Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Direct Phone: 502-357-9971; Office: 502-583-4022 ext 104; Email: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (new address noted).
- In the email footnotes, confidentiality notices were included in each message, indicating the communications are privileged and intended only for the named recipients.

In summary, the parties are coordinating deposition dates for Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al., with a plan to depoise Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo (and possibly Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason) around mid-to-late March, considering March 13, 18, 20, 25, or 27 as potential options if March 6 proves infeasible due to Ms. Vilches’ travel. A Spanish translator was requested, and a court-notice to the court reporter was planned. The Whaley Law Firm offered their conference room for the depositions and remains open to adjusting to April if needed.

episodes.natural_language:
This narrative summarizes the email communications and scheduling discussions between The Whaley Law Firm and SBMKY Law Firm, dated February 7 through March 13, 2025, concerning the deposition planning for Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al. in the Jeff Cir Court, case number 23-CI-006039, with Sariya Mason as the client.

On February 7, 2025 at 3:38 PM, Matthew R. Londergan (Attorney, SBMKY Law) informed Bryce that both clients are available on several dates: Thursday, February 20 after 11 a.m.; Thursday, March 6 any time; Thursday, March 13 any time; and Thursday, March 27 any time. He noted that a Spanish interpreter would be needed for these depositions and that Thursdays generally work best; if the listed dates did not work, they would obtain additional dates. His contact details were provided, and a confidentiality notice accompanied the message.

On February 9 or 10, 2025, Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm replied. In a message sent at 9:46 AM on February 10, she stated that March 6, 2025, beginning at 10:00 a.m., would work for their office, with Ms. Vilches first and Ms. Castillo in the afternoon, or vice versa; she asked whether they could use the sending office for the depositions to accommodate the parties. Her signature included her title, the firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and her direct line. A confidentiality notice was included in the email.

Later on February 10, 2025 at 11:04 AM, Sarena responded again: “Awesome, sounds great. We will get a notice over to you & the court reporter today,” reaffirming the plan and indicating they would issue the deposition notice to both the opposing party and the court reporter. This email also carried the standard confidentiality notice.

At 11:16 AM on February 10, 2025, Matthew Londergan replied that they would like to schedule his clients’ depositions in the same timeframe and asked Sarena to send dates when Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available in March or April. His message included his office address at 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, KY 40202, and his direct contact numbers, along with the confidentiality notice.

In a follow-up at 11:23 AM on February 10, 2025, Sarena sent the email with the attached NTTD (Notice to Take Depositions) for the defendants’ depositions and noted that they had requested a Spanish translator for the day. She also stated she had sent a request to Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason to check their availability and that she would update SBMKY as soon as she heard back. Her signature block again listed The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and new email address.

Sarena’s earlier message from February 10, 2025 at 11:04 AM was preceded by an earlier note stating, “Awesome, sounds great. We will get a notice over to you & the court reporter today,” confirming that a notice would be issued promptly.

On February 10, 2025 at 9:46 AM, Sarena had proposed the detailed schedule for March 6, 2025: beginning at 10:00 a.m. with Mrs. Vilches and continuing with Mrs. Castillo in the afternoon, or the order could be reversed; she asked whether it would be acceptable to use The Whaley Law Firm’s office for the depositions to facilitate the process.

By February 11, 2025 at 11:21 AM, Matthew informed Sarena that they had learned Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6. Ms. Castillo remained available on that day, but if the parties preferred to conduct both depositions on the same day, they had confirmed that both Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo would be available on any of the following days: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, and March 27. They also noted that a conference room was available at their office for the depositions on any of these dates, and they offered to arrange dates in April if none of the listed dates worked for the other side. He concluded by inviting a discussion over the phone if needed. His signature block again provided his office details: 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, KY 40202, with direct phone and fax numbers and the confidentiality notice.

Later on February 11, 2025 at 12:58:38 PM, Sarena replied to Matthew: “Good afternoon Matt, Thank you for the update & dates. We can move it to the 13th without an issue.” She confirmed acceptance of the proposed March 13 date and repeated that they could shift to that date given the updated availability, and she provided her contact details, including her new email address at The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct lines and email. The message itself did not include any additional scheduling details beyond confirming the March 13 option, but it did reiterate the shift to that date and acknowledged the update.

Across these exchanges, several consistent points appear: the depositions pertain to the Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al. matter in Jeff Cir Court, case 23-CI-006039; the clients involved include Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo, with Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason also mentioned for scheduling; a Spanish interpreter has been requested for the deposition day; The Whaley Law Firm offered use of its office space (including a conference room) to accommodate the depositions; the parties discussed scheduling across several potential dates, primarily in March 2025, with some consideration of April if needed; and the communications repeatedly included confidentiality notices and standard firm contact information, including the firm’s address, phone numbers, and Sarena’s new email address.

In sum, the correspondence documents a coordinated effort in February 2025 to schedule the depositions of the involved parties, balancing the availability of Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo, arranging for a Spanish translator, securing a conference room, and aligning dates so that the depositions for these related matters could be conducted efficiently, ultimately confirming March 13, 2025 as a feasible date for the depositions with permission to proceed on that day.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. This note covers communications regarding the deposition schedule in the matter Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al, Jeff Cir Court, 23-CI-006039.

On February 11, 2025, the Whaley Law Firm alerted SBMKY Law that Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available for depositions on March 18, 2025. The message came from Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, and included the firm’s contact details.

Earlier in the thread, Matthew R. Londergan of SBMKY Law had indicated they would inform their clients of potential dates. In response to scheduling needs, Sarena confirmed on February 10, 2025 that the defendants’ depositions would be conducted, beginning March 6, 2025 at 10:00 a.m. with Mrs. Vilches and continuing with Mrs. Castillo, and noted that a Spanish translator had been requested for that day. She also indicated she had sent a request to Mrs. Thomas and Sariya to check their availability and would provide an update as soon as she heard back. The same day, SBMKY stated that the conference room at their office would be available for the depositions on that date, and that the order of the depositions could be arranged as Whaley preferred.

Later that day, SBMKY reiterated that the conference room would be available and that they were flexible about the order of the depositions. On February 10, 2025 at 11:23 a.m., Sarena attached the Notice to Take Depositions (NTTD) for the Defendant’s Depositions and noted that a Spanish translator had been requested for the day; she also said she had asked Mrs. Thomas and Sariya to check their availability and would update Londergan as soon as she heard back.

At 11:21 a.m. on February 11, 2025, Londergan informed that Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, but Ms. Castillo would be available that day. He also indicated that if both depositions were to be conducted on the same day, both Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo would be available on any of these dates: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, or March 27. A conference room at SBMKY’s office would be available on any of these dates, and if none of these dates worked for the opposing office, dates in April could be arranged. He invited further discussion by phone.

Sarena responded on February 11, 2025 at 12:59 p.m., indicating that they could move the deposition to March 13 without issue. Matthew replied later that day at 1:22 p.m., saying they would inform their clients. Earlier in the thread, the initial note had stated that the depositions were to begin March 6, 2025 with Vilches and continue with the other party, with the possibility of rescheduling if needed.

In sum, the deposition plan involved coordinating the depositions of Mrs. Vilches and Mrs. Castillo around early March 2025, with contingencies for May/April dates if necessary, a Spanish translator for the day, and a conference-room venue. On February 11, 2025, it was noted that Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available on March 18, 2025, adding to the schedule of potential dates and confirming continued communication among all counsel.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
In the matter of Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al., Jeff Cir Crt, 23-CI-006039, the scheduling communications were exchanged in February 2025 between The Whaley Law Firm and Sariya Mason’s counsel, as part of the Sariya-Mason-DB file dated August 19, 2022. The depositions at issue involve Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason, with defendants including Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo, and the team planned to hold the depositions at the Whaley Law Firm office.

On February 10, 2025, Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm began outlining the plan. In a morning message, she stated that March 6, 2025 would begin at 10:00 a.m. with Mrs. Vilches and would continue with the other deponent. Matthew Londergan replied later that day, noting that the conference room at his office would be available that day and that Whaley could determine the deposition order. He followed up that same day by expressing readiness to send a notice to the court reporter and to coordinate with the clients.

Earlier that morning, multiple messages circulated regarding dates and coordination. Matthew asked for dates in March or April when Ms. Thomas and Sariya would be available, and Sarena attached a Notice to Take Depositions (NTTD) for the defendants’ depositions, along with a request for a Spanish translator for that day and a request for Mrs. Thomas and Sariya to confirm their availability. Kristy M. King, the legal assistant for Sariya Mason, also included a confidentiality notice in her communications.

Over the next hours, the parties discussed adjusting the schedule. Sarena indicated they could move the deposition date to March 13. Matthew noted that Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, but that Ms. Castillo would be available that day; he also advised that if both depositions were to occur on the same day, they had confirmed that both Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo would be available on any of the following mutually workable dates: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, and March 27. The Whaley team requested flexibility on the date and reminded that a conference room would be available at their office for whichever order the depositions occurred. If none of those dates worked, they suggested moving to April.

On February 11, 2025, further updates were exchanged. An earlier message from Matthew had requested that the parties’ availability be provided for March/April, and Sarena replied that they could move the depositions to March 13. Matthew followed by confirming that Ms. Vilches would now be unavailable on March 6, but that Ms. Castillo would still be available that day; the group remained open to scheduling both depositions on the same day on one of the dates listed (March 13, 18, 20, 25, or 27), with a court reporter and a conference room arranged at the office. She noted that they would update as soon as they heard back.

Sarena then informed Matthew that Mrs. Thomas and Sariya would be available on March 18, 2025. In parallel, Kristy M. King circulated that the 10:00 a.m. start time at The Whaley Law Firm’s office was being considered for the depositions.

Throughout these exchanges, new contact details surfaced: Sarena Tuttle noted a new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com) for future correspondence, and Kristy M. King’s signature appeared with the Whaley Law Firm’s Louisville address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222) and the firm’s phone and fax numbers.

In summary, the parties coordinated multiple schedules for the depositions in Schrice Thomas v. Castillo et al., with initial plans to begin on March 6, 2025 at 10:00 a.m. (Vilches first, then Castillo), the option to conduct both depositions on the same day, and subsequent adjustments moving toward March 13 or March 18, 2025, while ensuring a court reporter, a Spanish translator, an NTTD, and a suitable conference room setting were arranged.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. This note relates to Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al., before the Jeff Cir Crt, case number 23-CI-006039. The email thread consists of communications between Matthew R. Londergan of SBMKY Law and Sarena M. Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, with multiple recipients on CC and by email, concerning scheduling depositions for the defendants and the related Notice to Take Deposition (NTTD), including arrangements for a Spanish translator and a suitable venue.

The exchange began in early February 2025. On February 10, 2025, Matthew Londergan asked Sarena Tuttle to propose dates in March and April for the depositions of Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo, noting that a conference room at his office would be available for the depositions. He requested that they coordinate with their clients, Ms. Thomas and Sariya Mason, and keep him posted if anything changed. The initial message included his direct contact details and a confidentiality notice typical of attorney communications.

Later on February 10, Sarena responded that they had attached the Notice to Take Depositions (NTTD) for the Defendant’s Depositions and had requested a Spanish translator for that day. She indicated that she had sent a request to Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason to check their availability and promised to update as soon as responses were received. She also provided her contact information and noted a new Whaley Law Firm email address in the chain. In a follow-up, she confirmed that they would get a notice to Matthew and the court reporter that day, reiterating the plan to coordinate the depositions.

On February 10, 2025, Matthew replied that the conference room at his office was available and that either order of depositions would be acceptable. He reiterated his willingness to accommodate the scheduling and to notify the clients accordingly. Sarena then attached the NTTD and again affirmed the availability of a Spanish translator, along with the standard confidentiality notice.

Later on February 11, 2025, Sarena indicated that they could move the depositions to March 13 without issue. In response, Matthew noted that he had learned Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, and that while Ms. Castillo was available that day, they could schedule both depositions on the same day if desired. He reported that both Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo would be available on any of the following days: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, or March 27, and he reminded that a conference room was available at their office for the depositions. He also offered to discuss further if needed. This message thread contains the standard confidentiality notices on each email.

On February 11, 2025 at 12:59 PM, Sarena confirmed once more that they could move to March 13. At 1:22 PM, Matthew responded, “Great, thank you. We will let our clients know.” Later that same day, Sarena informed Matthew that they had just heard back from Mrs. Thomas, and that both Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available on March 18, 2025. In the final note from February 11, 2025 at 7:12 PM, Matthew thanked her and stated that they would get the depositions noticed for their office on March 18, and asked to be informed if anything changed in the meantime.

Across the thread, the parties discussed the Notice to Take Depositions, arranged for a Spanish translator, and coordinated availability for two defendants’ depositions—Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo—while reserving the office conference room for the proceedings. The stated plan, as of the latest update, is to notice the depositions for March 18, 2025, with flexibility to adjust to alternative dates (March 13, 18, 20, 25, 27) if needed, and to proceed with both depositions on the same day if feasible.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al., Jefferson Circuit Court, 23-CI-006039, was the subject of a series of scheduling emails in February 2025 involving the representation for Sariya Mason (the client) and counsel for the other side. The Whaley Law Firm, on behalf of Sariya Mason, coordinated depositions in the matter with SBMKY Law. In the initial exchange, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, sent to Kristy M. King and cc’d colleagues a notice that included an attached Notice to Take the Deposition of the Defendant (NTTD) and a request for a Spanish translator for the day, noting that she had reached out to Mrs. Thomas and Sariya to check their availability and would provide updates.

On February 10, 2025, Kristy M. King asked whether a 10:00 a.m. start at their office would be acceptable for the depositions. In reply, Sarena confirmed a positive response: “Absolutely. Thank you so much,” and signed with her updated contact information. Earlier that same day, Kristy’s team had proposed a potential schedule, and Matthew R. Londergan, an attorney for SBMKY, had asked for dates in March and April to align depositions for Ms. Thomas and Sariya.

Later on February 10, 2025, Sarena told Matthew that they could move the deposition date to the 13th without issue. The next day, February 11, 2025, Matthew informed Sarena that they had learned Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, and that Ms. Castillo was available that day. He added that, if both depositions were to occur on the same day, they had confirmed that both Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo would be available at any time on the following dates: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, and March 27, and that a conference room would be available at their office for the depositions on any of those dates; if none of these dates worked for the other office, they could pursue dates in April. 

Sarena replied that the plan sounded good and that they would issue a notice to the court reporter that day. A subsequent message from Sarena to Matthew acknowledged the new dates, stating that moving the deposition to the 13th was not a problem. Matthew then responded, thanking her and saying they would inform their clients. Later that day, Sarena noted that they had heard back from Mrs. Thomas, who, along with Sariya Mason, would be available on March 18, 2025. Kristy then inquired about starting the depositions at 10:00 a.m. at their office, to which Sarena replied, “Absolutely. Thank you so much, Kristy,” and signed her message with her full contact information, including her new email address.

For reference, the communications included the following contact details and identifiers: Sarena M. Tuttle, The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial 502-357-9971; office 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com (noting the new address). Kristy M. King’s office address appeared as 401 West Main Street, Suite 1600, Louisville, KY 40202, with direct phone 502-625-1706 and direct fax 502-583-4780. The depositions were to be held in the presenting firm’s conference room, with dates proposed for March 13, 18, 20, 25, and 27, and a March 6 option previously discussed due to Ms. Vilches’ travel, all subject to the availability of Mrs. Thomas (Schrice Thomas) and Sariya Mason for the day and the possible need for a Spanish translator.

episodes.natural_language:
The case is Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022, and the client is Sariya Mason. On February 12, 2025 at 10:16:08 AM Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to the Kentuckiana Reporters Scheduling Department with a new submission from 20 Second Scheduler. In that message, she advised that the Defense has requested the deposition be moved to March 13, 2025. The deposition time remains 10:00 a.m., and the location remains DC Office, 401 W. Main Street, 16th Floor, Louisville, KY 40202, with a translator still required. She noted that an Amended Notice is attached and invited any questions. Sarena’s signature includes her contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, and a parenthetical note to please note the new email address.

Earlier, on February 10, 2025, around 11:56 AM, the Scheduling Department replied: they would add these to their calendar and work on reserving a Spanish interpreter. The response came from the Kentuckiana Reporters Scheduling Team, which included Kristina Rahm, McKenna Watson, and Madison Elam, and provided standard contact details: P: 502-589-2273; E: Schedule@kentuckianareporters.com; A: 730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202. The department also included their cancellation policy, which states that a cancellation fee applies for all assignments canceled with less than 24 hours’ notice, and that interpreter requests canceled within 24 hours will be billed at the industry standard of a 2-hour minimum rate.

Additionally, the donotreply message from Kentuckiana Reporters, sent on February 10, 2025 at 11:14 AM, confirms a new submission from 20 Second Scheduler. It lists the Name as Sarena Tuttle and the Email as Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with the Additional Comments: “Def Deposition x2 - In Person - DC Office - Spanish Translator Required.” The notice attached to that submission is named 2025.02.10-Mason-NTTD-Defs-03.06.2025-10a-EST-DC-Office.pdf.

In sum, the latest plan is to hold two depositions in person at the DC Office in Louisville, Kentucky, with a Spanish translator required, under the updated schedule moving the deposition to March 13, 2025 at 10:00 a.m., at 401 W. Main Street, 16th Floor, Louisville, KY 40202, with the Amended Notice attached to the Feb. 12, 2025 email from Sarena Tuttle. The prior correspondence confirms the scheduling team’s intent to add these events to the calendar and reserve the Spanish interpreter, and it reiterates the firm’s contact details and cancellation policies.

Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. This matter concerns a new submission from 20 Second Scheduler. The thread begins with an email from the Scheduling Department at Kentuckiana Reporters to Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, dated February 12, 2025 at 16:06:56 UTC, acknowledging the submission and stating that they would update their records. The Scheduling Team signature includes Kristina Rahm, McKenna Watson, and Madison Elam, with contact information for Kentuckiana Reporters: 730 West Main Street, Suite 101, Louisville, KY 40202; phone 502-589-2273; email Schedule@kentuckianareporters.com.

Earlier in the chain, on February 10, 2025 at 11:14 AM, a message from donotreply@kentuckianareporters.com on behalf of donotreply@kentuckianareporters.com was sent to Scheduling Department. It was sent by Sarena Tuttle (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com) and included the following details in the Additional Comments: Def Deposition x2 - In Person - DC Office - Spanish Translator Required. It also included a Notice file titled 2025.02.10-Mason-NTTD-Defs-03.06.2025-10a-EST-DC-Office.pdf.

The Scheduling Department replied about an hour later, at 11:56 AM, confirming that they would add these to their calendar and work on reserving a Spanish interpreter. Their reply came from the Kentuckiana Reporters Scheduling Team and reiterated their cancellation policy: a cancellation fee will apply for any assignment cancelled with less than 24-hours’ notice, and interpreter cancellations within 24 hours are billed at the industry standard of a 2-hour minimum rate. The standard signature block appeared, listing Kristina Rahm, McKenna Watson, and Madison Elam, along with the same contact details for Kentuckiana Reporters.

On February 12, 2025 at 10:16 AM, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note that a new email address is in use), responded to Scheduling Department. She informed them that the Defense had requested the deposition be moved to March 13, 2025. The time remained 10:00 AM, and the location remained the DC Office at 401 W. Main Street, 16th Floor, Louisville, KY 40202. She also noted that a translator would still be required and advised that an Amended Notice was attached for discussion.

Later that same day, February 12, 2025, at 16:06 UTC, the Scheduling Department replied to Sarena with, “Got it! We’ll get this updated on our end. Thanks!” The message was sent under the Kentuckiana Reporters Scheduling Team, and the signature block again listed Kristina Rahm, McKenna Watson, and Madison Elam, along with the same contact details and the repeated cancellation policy.

Across these communications, the following additional contextual details appear in the chain: the initial submission was titled “New submission from 20 Second Scheduler,” and the Amended Notice referenced by Sarena was attached in her February 12 message. The record also shows the inclusion of standard cancellation terms—the 24-hour notice rule and the 2-hour minimum for interpreter cancellations. The parties’ contact details appear repeatedly: The Whaley Law Firm’s contact page shows Sarena’s address and numbers, including the note to use the new email address, Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. Kentuckiana Reporters’ contact details are also included, with their Louisville office address, phone number, and email.

__CLIENT CONTACT__
__Details:__ Recvd DC Email - Cancelled tomorrow's Deposition of Client & Guardian - Sent Guardian Update via Text

Good morning Schrice,
 We greatly apologize, The Defense Counsel has reached out & advised us that she has a scheduling conflict and can not attend tomorrow's deposition of Sariya & yourself. Please rest assured that we will get this back on the calendar as soon as possible to avoid any further delays in the claim. Please enjoy your day tomorrow and we will reach out as soon as we have a new date finalized. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail. -Sarena, The Whaley Law Firm

__Date & Time__: March 17 2025

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022
Client: Sariya Mason

This record concerns the matter Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al, in Jeff Cir Crt, case number 23-CI-006039. The deposition scheduling communications involve counsel from The Whaley Law Firm and from SBMKY Law, with the Plaintiffs Mr. Vilches, Mrs. Castillo, Mrs. Thomas, and Sariya Mason referenced in various positions in the thread. The note begins with a recent scheduling conflict raised by Kristy M. King, a legal assistant, on March 17, 2025, who asked for new dates after advising of a conflict for tomorrow and noting the need to reschedule the Plaintiffs’ depositions.

In the run-up to these dates, the calendar coordination unfolded through a sequence of emails in February 2025. On February 10, 2025, Matthew R. Londergan, an attorney with the Whaley/Belmont group, requested that the two depositions—those of Ms. Thomas and Sariya—be scheduled in the same timeframe and asked for dates in March or April that would work for the counsel and the Plaintiffs. The response from Sarena M. Tuttle was prompt. She indicated “Absolutely” and sent back information, noting that the firm had attached the NTTD (Notice to Take Depositions) for the Defendant’s Depositions and that a Spanish translator was being requested for that day. She also said she had asked Mrs. Thomas and Sariya to check their availability and that she would provide updates as soon as she heard back.

Earlier in the day, there was an initial note from Sarena replying “Awesome” to the request, followed by further detail in the subsequent communications. Also on February 10, 2025, Sarena referenced that Kristy had asked whether a 10:00 a.m. start at SBMKY’s office would be suitable for the depositions.

The thread then shows a key development on February 11, 2025. Matthew Londergan informed Sarena that they had learned Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6. Ms. Castillo would still be available on that date, and the two depositions could be conducted on the same day if desired. The teams confirmed that Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo would be available at any time on any of the following days: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, and March 27. A conference room at their office was also available on these dates. They noted that if none of these dates worked for the other office, April dates could be considered.

In response to the proposed dates, Sarena advised that they could move the deposition to March 13 without issue. Matthew responded that they would inform their clients. Sarena then noted that Mrs. Thomas and Sariya had responded and would be available on March 18, 2025. Kristy asked for confirmation about a 10:00 a.m. start at their office for the depositions, and Sarena replied with “Awesome,” confirming readiness to proceed under that arrangement.

Across these exchanges, the communications repeatedly referenced confidentiality notices attached to each email and the need to handle discovery with attorney-client/work product privileges preserved.

By February 11, 2025, the parties had established potential dates on which both Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo could be deposed (March 13, 18, 20, 25, or 27), with arrangements for a conference room at the defense office if needed, and with the additional detail that a Spanish translator would be requested for the day. The availability updates indicated that Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available on March 18, 2025, and that the 10:00 a.m. start at the defense office was being considered.

On March 17, 2025, Kristy M. King sent a new email noting a scheduling conflict for tomorrow and requesting that additional dates be provided that would work for both counsel and the Plaintiffs, Sariya Mason and Mrs. Thomas, in order to reschedule the Plaintiffs’ depositions. She asked for alternative dates and apologized for the late notice.

In summary, the record reflects a coordinated effort in February 2025 to schedule the depositions of the Plaintiffs in Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al., with proposed dates including March 13, 18, 20, 25, and 27, consideration of Ms. Vilches and Ms. Castillo’s availability, a plan to use a conference room at the defense office, and a request for a 10:00 a.m. start on the days chosen. By mid-March, a scheduling conflict prompted a request for additional date options to accommodate counsel and the Plaintiffs, including Sariya Mason and Mrs. Thomas. Throughout, confidentiality notices accompanied each message.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Sariya-Mason-DB-08-19-2022. Client: Sariya Mason. This note concerns the deposition scheduling for plaintiffs in Schrice Thomas v. Yanelys Castillo et al., Jeff Cir Court, 23-CI-006039. The communications involve The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for Sariya Mason) and SBMKY Law (Kristy M. King, Matthew R. Londergan, Bryce Koon, Deanna M. Tucker, Benji Smith). The thread covers proposed dates, available slots, and changes due to conflicts, with repeated references to the new email address for Sarena.

On February 10, 2025, Sarena Tuttle told Matthew Londergan: “Absolutely,” and noted that she attached the NTTD for the Defendant’s Depositions and that they had requested a Spanish Tr—the line ends at “Tr” in the record. In her signature, she also indicated a new email address: Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. Earlier messages dated February 11, 2025 show the parties discussing available dates and logistics for the depositions. Matthew Londergan replied that Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, but Ms. Castillo would be available that day; if both depositions were to be on the same day, they could be scheduled on any of the following days: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, or March 27, with a conference room available at their office. He also noted that if none of those dates worked, they would propose dates in April. He added that he would let their clients know. Earlier in the thread, Sarena had indicated that they could move the deposition date to the 13th without issue, and Matthew confirmed their clients’ availability for the proposed dates, including Mrs. Thomas and Sariya being available on March 18, 2025.

Kristy M. King also contributed to the scheduling discussion, asking on February 11, 2025 at 2:12 p.m. whether a 10:00 a.m. start at their office would be okay for the depositions. In response, Sarena Tuttle affirmed with a brief reply at 2:45 p.m., saying, “Absolutely. Thank you so much Kristy,” and again providing her contact details with the new address.

Earlier in the thread, on February 11, 2025 at 12:59 p.m., Sarena told Matthew that they could move the deposition to the 13th without issue. In a separate message, dated February 11, 2025 at 1:50 p.m., Sarena also advised that they had heard back from Mrs. Thomas, and that both Mrs. Thomas and Sariya would be available on March 18, 2025.

Continuing the exchange, on February 11, 2025 at 1:22 p.m., Matthew wrote, “Awesome. We also just heard back from Mrs. Thomas. Her & Sariya will be available on March 18, 2025.” He later thanked Sarena for the update, saying they would relay the information to their clients. The thread also notes a conference room would be available for the depositions at SBMKY’s office on the dates discussed, and that if the proposed dates did not work, April dates would be sought.

In the later portion of the exchange, on February 10–11, 2025, Sarena reiterated the attached NTTD for the Defendant’s Depositions and their request for a Spanish translator (the line ends with “Tr,” indicating the sentence was not completed in the record). The thread includes repeated confidentiality notices common to these attorney communications, along with signatures that consistently display Sarena’s new email address.

Finally, on March 17, 2025, Kristy M. King reported a scheduling conflict for tomorrow and requested additional dates that would work for counsel and plaintiffs, apologizing for the late notice. In response, later that same day, Sarena acknowledged the conflict, stated that the beginning of April is tricky due to Spring Break and vacations, and proposed looking at dates the week after Easter. She listed April 22, 23, 24, 29, 30, or May 1 as open and asked which of those dates would work best for Kristy’s office.

episodes.natural_language:
This note summarizes the scheduling communications for depositions in the case Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al., Jeff Cir Crt, 23-CI-006039, with client Sariya Mason. The involved law firms are The Whaley Law Firm (Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and colleagues Matthew Londergan, Bryce Koon, Deanna M. Tucker, and Benji Smith) and SBM Kentucky Law ( Kristy M. King, a Legal Assistant, and Mr. Matthew Londergan as the client contact). The depositions at issue concern Plaintiffs, including Sariya Mason, and the parties have been coordinating through email exchanges that span February and March 2025. Each email contained a confidentiality notice stating that the communication and attachments are confidential and privileged and should be treated accordingly.

Beginning in mid-February 2025, the parties discussed dates for the plaintiffs’ depositions and the logistics of where and when they would occur. In a February 11 exchange, the Whaley firm advised that the depositions could be moved to March 13 without issue, and that the depositions could be held in their office with a conference room available for use on any of the proposed dates. They noted that Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, and that Ms. Castillo would be available on that day if both depositions were desired on the same day. The Whaley team listed several potential dates for depositions: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, and March 27, with the option to reschedule into April if those dates did not work. They also indicated that Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available on March 18, 2025. In addition, they proposed a 10:00 a.m. start time for the depositions at their office. Matthew Londergan acknowledged the proposed dates and noted that he would inform their clients.

Later on February 11, 2025, Matthew Londergan confirmed that Ms. Vilches would be unavailable on March 6 due to being out of the country, but that Ms. Castillo remained available on that date. He reiterated the available dates for scheduling: March 13, March 18, March 20, March 25, and March 27, with a conference room available at their office. He suggested that if both depositions could be held on the same day, they would coordinate accordingly. The Whaley team responded affirmatively to the 10:00 a.m. start time, and the exchange continued with further confirmations about the dates and client availability. Matthew later indicated that he would inform their clients of the proposed schedule, and Sarena replied, “Absolutely,” expressing appreciation for Kristy’s coordination.

In the same February 11 thread, there is a rapid back-and-forth about timing and client availability. The Whaley team confirmed that moving to March 13 was acceptable, and they provided the March 18 availability for Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason. They also confirmed that depositions could start at 10:00 a.m. at the SBM Kentucky office, and that a conference room would be available for the depositions. The sequence also shows ongoing coordination regarding whether both depositions should occur on the same day and how best to accommodate the calendar constraints, with the parties showing flexibility about April dates if March dates proved impractical.

By March 17, 2025, scheduling again required adjustment due to conflicts in early April. Kristy M. King conveyed that there had been a scheduling conflict for the next day and asked for additional dates that would work for counsel and the Plaintiffs. She noted that Mr. Londergan was available on April 29, 30, and May 1 and asked if there was a preferred date or start time. Kristy’s message closed with her standard confirmation and contact details. The Whaley firm replied with a plan to consider the later dates and asked for guidance on preferred times.

In response to Kristy’s March 17 message, Sarena Tuttle provided a clear set of alternative open dates in the week after Easter: April 22, 23, 24, 29, and 30, as well as May 1. She asked Kristy to indicate which of these dates would work best for her office. This offered window reflects ongoing collaborative scheduling between the two firms to finalize the depositions for the plaintiffs, including Sariya Mason and Mrs. Thomas, in this Jefferson Circuit Court case.

Additional context within the chain shows prior back-and-forth in February about possible start times (with at one point a suggested 10:00 a.m. start) and the availability of the parties. There are references to both Ms. Castillo and Ms. Vilches, and to coordinating depositions either on separate days or on the same day, with the option to move to April if March dates could not be arranged. Throughout, the discussions emphasize the need to accommodate Spring Breaks, vacations, and travel constraints, while securing a suitable conference-room space at the scheduling firm’s office.

In short, the parties have been negotiating depositions for Schrice Thomas v Yanelys Castillo et al., with plaintiffs including Sariya Mason. Initial February exchanges proposed multiple March dates (including March 13, 18, 20, 25, and 27) and a 10:00 a.m. start, subject to availability of a conference room at the filing firm’s offices. Availability updates indicated that Mrs. Thomas and Sariya Mason would be available on March 18, and that Ms. Vilches would be out of the country on March 6, with other days available for scheduling. By mid-March, Mr. Londergan’s availability moved to late April and early May (April 29, 30, and May 1), and Sarena offered open dates in late April and early May (April 22–24, 29–30, and May 1), requesting confirmation of which option worked best for Kristy’s office. The correspondence remains confidential and privileged, as noted in each email.
